{{Infobox convention | name = Nycon I, the 1st World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = Caravan Hall | location = [[New York City]] | country = United States | first = July 2–4, 1939 | last = | organizer = | filing = | attendance = 200 | website = }} The '''First World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]) was held in the Caravan Hall in [[New York City|New York]] from July 2 to July 4, 1939, in conjunction with the [[1939 New York World's Fair|New York World's Fair]], which was themed as "The World of Tomorrow". The convention was later named "'''Nycon I'''" by [[Forrest J Ackerman]]. The event had 200 participants. ==Participants== The Guest of Honor at the first [[Worldcon]] was [[Frank R. Paul]] and the event was chaired by [[Sam Moskowitz]]. Along with Moskowitz, other organizers were [[James V. Taurasi]] and [[Will Sykora]]. Notable people attending included [[John W. Campbell]], [[Isaac Asimov]], [[L. Sprague de Camp]], [[Ray Bradbury]], [[Hannes Bok]], [[Milton A. Rothman]], [[John Drury Clark|John D. Clark]], [[Jack Williamson]], and [[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]]. In addition to its groundbreaking role as the first of its kind, the convention was noteworthy for the exclusion of a number of politicized [[Futurians]] by convention chair Sam Moskowitz; those excluded were [[Donald A. Wollheim]], [[Frederick Pohl]], John Michel, [[Robert A. W. Lowndes]], and [[Jack Gillespie]], an event known to [[science fiction fandom|fannish historians]] as "The Great Exclusion Act." According to Pohl, in his autobiography ''[[The Way the Future Was]]'', the Futurians held their own counter-convention which was attended by several who went to the regular convention. He also downplayed the aspect that politics played, himself believing that it was a personality conflict between the convention organizers and the Futurians and said "We pretty nearly had it coming," continuing with "What we Futurians made very clear to the rest of New York fandom was that we thought we were better than they were. For some reason that annoyed them."Frederik Pohl, ''The Way The Future Was'', Ballantine/Del Rey Books, 1978, p.94 Ackerman and his girlfriend and fellow [[science fiction fanzines|fanzine]] editor Myrtle R. Douglas ("Morojo") attended the convention in costumes designed and sewn by Douglas: this is considered a forerunner to modern [[cosplay|fan costuming]] (which is known as "cosplay").{{cite news |first=Adam K. |last=Raymond |publisher=[[Yahoo! Movies]] |title=75 Years Of Capes and Face Paint: A History of Cosplay |url=https://www.yahoo.com/movies/75-years-of-capes-and-face-paint-a-history-of-cosplay-92666923267.html |date=July 24, 2014 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}} ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==Notes== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |title=The Press: Amazing! Astounding! |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,761661-1,00.html |date=July 10, 1939 |accessdate=March 7, 2011}} {{cite news |first=Peter J. |last=Henniker-Heaton |work=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |title=From the Bookshelf |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/csmonitor_historic/access/200603302.html?dids=200603302:200603302&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI |date=July 6, 1963 |accessdate=March 8, 2011 |quote=Sam Moskowitz has written science fiction, taught it, been an editor and literary agent in the field, and in 1939 organized the first of the still continuing World Science Fiction Conventions.}} {{cite news|last=Kyle |first=David |authorlink=David Kyle |title=SaM - Fan Forever (Moskowitz, the Futurians, and the Great Exclusion Act of 1939) |work=Mimosa |issue=21 |url=http://www.jophan.org/mimosa/m21/kyle.htm |date=December 1997 |accessdate=21 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401064731/http://jophan.org/mimosa/m21/kyle.htm |archivedate=1 April 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{cite news |last=Kyle |first=David |authorlink=David Kyle |title=Caravan to the Stars |work=Mimosa |url=http://www.jophan.org/mimosa/m29/kyle.htm |issue=29 |date=December 2002| accessdate= 10 December 2008 }} {{cite web |work=Notes on the Long List of Worldcons |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |title=1939 - Nycon I |url=http://www.smofinfo.com/LL/LongListNotes.html#1939 |accessdate=March 7, 2011}} {{cite web |title=The Long List of World Science Fiction Conventions |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |url=http://www.smofinfo.com/LL/TheLongList.html |accessdate=March 7, 2011}} }} == References == * ''In Memory Yet Green'' by [[Isaac Asimov]] (1979) * ''The Futurians'' by [[Damon Knight]] (1977) * ''The Way The Future Was'' by [[Frederik Pohl]] (1978) == External links== *[http://www.wsfs.org/ World Science Fiction Society] *[http://fanac.org/worldcon/NYcon/w39-p00.html NYcon 1 - {{Update|date=November 2017}} The '''2015–17 FIBA–Euroleague Basketball controversy''' was a dispute between [[FIBA]] and [[Euroleague Basketball]] over control of the premier Europe-wide professional [[sports club|club]] [[basketball]] competition.
==Background== {{main|FIBA European Champions Cup and EuroLeague history}} The [[EuroLeague]] was originally established by [[FIBA Europe]], and it operated under its umbrella from 1958 until summer 2000, concluding with the [[1999–2000 FIBA EuroLeague|1999–00 season]]. That was when the richest and most popular European basketball clubs created [[Euroleague Basketball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportcal.com/News/FeaturedNews/104412?sportID=58|title=Munich court lifts injunction blocking FIBA sanctions, but Euroleague pledges to remain vigilant - Featured News- News - Sportcal|author=|date=|website=www.Sportcal.com|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref>
FIBA had never trademarked the "EuroLeague" name, even though it had used that name for the competition since 1996. Euroleague Basketball simply appropriated the name, and since FIBA had no [[legal recourse]] to do anything about it, it was forced to find a new name for its championship series.<ref name="The unknown war">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/featured/322922/the-unknown-war|title=The unknown war - Eurohoops|author=|date=7 October 2016|website=Eurohoops.net|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref> Thus, the following 2000–2001 season had two separate European club competitions: the [[FIBA SuproLeague]] and the new [[Euroleague 2000–01|Euroleague 2000–01 season]].<ref name="The unknown war"/>
Top clubs were also split between the two leagues: [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos]], [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]], [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], and [[Anadolu Efes S.K.|Efes Pilsen]] stayed with FIBA, while [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]], [[Virtus Pallacanestro Bologna|Kinder Bologna]], [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]], [[FC Barcelona Bàsquet|FC Barcelona]], [[Saski Baskonia|Baskonia]], and [[Pallacanestro Treviso|Benetton Treviso]] joined Euroleague Basketball.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/archive-news-detail.aspx?pageID=438&n=european-basketball-split-into-two-2000-07-14|title=Hürriyet Daily News - Archive news detail|author=|date=14 July 2000|website=Hürriyet Daily News - LEADING NEWS SOURCE FOR TURKEY AND THE REGION|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref>
In May 2001, Europe had two first-tier continental champions, Maccabi of the FIBA SuproLeague, and Kinder Bologna of the Euroleague. The leaders of both organizations realized the need to come up with a unified competition. Although only a year old, Euroleague Basketball negotiated from a position of strength, and dictated proceedings. FIBA essentially had no choice but to agree to Euroleague Basketball's terms. As a result, European club basketball competition was fully integrated under Euroleague Basketball's umbrella, and some teams that competed in the FIBA SuproLeague during the 2000–01 season joined it as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballineurope.com/we-really-dont-need-another-civil-war/|title=We really don't need another civil war - BallinEurope|author=|date=18 March 2015|website=BallinEurope.com|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref>
In November 2004, FIBA and EuroLeague officially came to an agreement. In essence, authority in European professional basketball competitions was divided along club-country lines. FIBA remained in charge of national team competitions (like the [[FIBA EuroBasket]], the [[FIBA World Cup|World Championships]], and the [[Basketball at the Summer Olympics|Olympics]]), while Euroleague Basketball took over the European professional club competitions. From that point on, FIBA's [[Korać Cup]] and [[Saporta Cup]] competitions, which had recently folded, were replaced by Euroleague Basketball's recently-launched ULEB Cup, later renamed the [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_W75uhWDHGZoQ13nPGyAbv1.coid_UTUQprseGSUi0MX10W8A60.articleMode_on.html|title=FIBA Europe and ULEB Sign Historic Agreement In Geneva - FIBA Europe|author=|date=|website=www.FIBAEurope.com|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref>
==Controversy== In June 2015, [[FIBA]] announced it would start a new league to compete with [[Euroleague Basketball]]'s second-tier [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/season_2015.coid_CZeceN8pG,2b-CaAGL1dh0.articleMode_on.html|title=FIBA Europe Board pushes ahead with attractive club competitions model|date=30 June 2015|publisher=FIBA Europe|access-date=}}</ref> In July 2015, FIBA also tried to take the helm of the [[EuroLeague]], by trying to convince eight of the eleven teams with a EuroLeague A-Licence to play in a new FIBA competition instead of the EuroLeague.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talkbasket.net/16281-fiba-ready-to-shake-up-the-european-club-competition.html|publisher=TalkBasket|title=FIBA ready to shake up the European club competition|date=8 July 2015|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref> This proposal was unanimously rejected by the EuroLeague clubs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/66rba6ti6umdklcy/euroleague-commercial-assets-and-a-licence-clubs-issue-joint-communication-to-fiba|title=Euroleague Commercial Assets and A-Licence clubs issue joint communication to FIBA|publisher=Euroleague|date=8 July 2015|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref>
In October 2015, FIBA attempted to take back control of Europe's first-tier club competition,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/pr65-fiba-to-welcome-top-european-clubs-for-talks-on-new-competition|title=FIBA to welcome top European clubs for talks on new competition|publisher=FIBA|date=27 October 2015|access-date=21 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/pr-68-fiba-offers-innovative-partnership-to-top-european-clubs|title=FIBA offers innovative partnership to top European clubs|publisher=FIBA|date=3 November 2015|access-date=21 March 2016}}</ref> proposing the [[Basketball Champions League]], a new league that would have 16 teams, playing in a round-robin format, and granting eight guaranteed spots to different clubs.
In November 2015, Euroleague Basketball agreed to a 10-year marketing [[joint venture]] with [[IMG (company)|IMG]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/6gt4utknkf9h8ryq|title=Euroleague Basketball A-licence clubs and IMG agree on 10-year joint venture|publisher=Euroleague Basketball|date=10 November 2015|access-date=12 November 2015}}</ref> In its press release, the EuroLeague announced a new competition format for the [[2016–17 EuroLeague|2016–17 season]], with only 16 teams, including the eleven A-license clubs ([[Anadolu Efes S.K.|Anadolu Efes]], [[Saski Baskonia|Baskonia]], [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], [[FC Barcelona Bàsquet|FC Barcelona]], [[Fenerbahçe Men's Basketball|Fenerbahçe]], [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]], [[Pallacanestro Olimpia Milano|Olimpia Milano]], [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]], [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos]], [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]], and [[BC Žalgiris|Žalgiris]]), playing in only one group, with a double round-robin, a true league format, with the top eight placed teams from the regular season then playing in a best-of-five playoffs round to decide qualification to the [[2017 EuroLeague Final Four]].
After its initial proposal was rejected by the EuroLeague clubs, FIBA changed the format of the Basketball Champions League, with qualification based on performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://basketballcl.com/16-17/news/basketball-champions-league-working-groups-make-significant-headway |title=Basketball Champions League Working Groups make significant headway |publisher=BasketballCL.com |date=28 January 2016 |access-date=21 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321191031/http://basketballcl.com/16-17/news/basketball-champions-league-working-groups-make-significant-headway |archivedate=21 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> This competition was officially launched on 22 March 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.basketballcl.com/pr-73-fiba-confirms-launch-of-basketball-champions-league-for-2016-17-season|title=FIBA confirms launch of Basketball Champions League for 2016-17 season|publisher=BasketballCL.com|date=26 November 2015|access-date=21 March 2016}}</ref>
===Threats of suspension of 14 national teams=== Despite the offer of FIBA to all European national basketball federations, many clubs instead agreed with EuroLeague to participate in the [[2016–17 EuroLeague]], or [[2016–17 EuroCup Basketball|2016–17 EuroCup]]. Regional leagues like the [[ABA League|Adriatic League]] and [[VTB United League]], as well as many national domestic leagues, signed contracts with Euroleague Basketball for the right to participate in its competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/6t74py47vpaqpt68|title=Euroleague and Eurocup competition structures set for 2016-17|publisher=Euroleague Basketball|date=11 April 2016|access-date=11 April 2016}}</ref>
Because of this support for EuroLeague, FIBA threatened to suspend 14 European basketball federations from [[EuroBasket 2017]]. Notified national organisations were given a five-day period, until 20 April 2016, to explain their stance on the situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/national-teams/national-teams/197147/fiba-europe-reportedly-suspended-14-national-federations-from-eurobasket-2017.html|title=FIBA reportedly suspended 14 national federations from Eurobasket 2017|publisher=Sportando|date=15 April 2016|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/sport/kosarka/vesti.php?yyyy=2016&mm=04&dd=16&nav_id=1120583|title=FIBA threatens suspension of 14 national federations from Eurobasket 2017|publisher=B92|date=15 April 2016|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|user=yugobasket|author=Yugobasket|number=721081044942917634|date=15 April 2016|title=Full letter regarding the suspension of Slovenian Basketball Federation by FIBA:}}</ref> These federations are:
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|- ! National basketball federation ! Men's national team |- | {{flagicon|Bosnia}} [[Basketball Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] | {{bk|BIH}} |- | {{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Croatian Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|CRO}} |- | {{flagicon|Greece}} [[Hellenic Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|GRE}} |- | {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Israel Basketball Association]] | {{bk|ISR}} |- | {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Italian Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|ITA}} |- | {{flagicon|Lithuania}} [[Lithuanian Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|LTU}} |- | {{flagicon|Spain}} [[Spanish Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|ESP}} |- | {{flagicon|Macedonia}} [[Basketball Federation of Macedonia]] | {{bk|MKD}} |- | {{flagicon|Montenegro}} [[Basketball Federation of Montenegro]] | {{bk|MNE}} |- | {{flagicon|Poland}} [[Polish Basketball Association]] | {{bk|POL}} |- | {{flagicon|Russia}} [[Russian Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|RUS}} |- | {{flagicon|Serbia}} [[Basketball Federation of Serbia]] | {{bk|SRB}} |- | {{flagicon|Slovenia}} [[Basketball Federation of Slovenia]] | {{bk|SVN}} |- | {{flagicon|Turkey}} [[Turkish Basketball Federation]] | {{bk|TUR}} |}
On 16 April 2016, FIBA asked Germany to take over the hosting of the [[2016 FIBA World Olympic Qualifying Tournament – Turin|2016 FIBA World Olympic Qualifying Tournament]] from Italy, which was at risk of suspension.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/national-teams/national-teams/197172/fiba-asks-to-germany-the-possibility-to-organize-olympic-qualifying-tournament.html|title=FIBA asks to Germany the possibility to organize Olympic Qualifying Tournament|publisher=Sportando|date=16 April 2016|access-date=16 April 2016}}</ref> In the end, no suspensions were applied.
====Reactions to the possible suspension====
=====Greece===== Giorgios Nikolau, director of communications of [[AEK Athens B.C.|AEK Athens]], after its defeat against [[P.A.O.K. B.C.|PAOK]], in the first game of the [[2016 Greek Basket League Playoffs|Greek League quarterfinals]], stated that his club, "will not be blackmailed by anyone, and doesn’t get any kind of messages by anyone".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/featured/226562/aek-will-not-be-blackmailed|title=AEK will not be blackmailed|publisher=Eurohoops|date=16 April 2016|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref> AEK had previously agreed to a three-year contract with EuroLeague Basketball to participate in [[EuroCup Basketball]].{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
=====Lithuania===== On 20 April 2016, the [[Lithuanian Basketball Federation]] suspended [[BC Lietuvos rytas]] for their agreement with EuroLeague. Subsequently, the club from [[Vilnius]] would be disqualified from the [[Lithuanian Basketball League]] (LKL).<ref name="Lietuvos Rytas">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/fiba/228990/lithuanian-federation-to-suspend-lietuvos-rytas|title=Lithuanian Federation to suspend Lietuvos Rytas|publisher=Eurohoops|date=20 April 2016|access-date=25 April 2016}}</ref> Remigijus Milašius, president of the LKL, refuted their arguments and said that, FIBA "promised a lot of money, which they do not even have".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.basketnews.lt/news-97243-lkl-prezidentas-milasius-lyga-niekada-nepaliks-zalgirio-ir-lietuvos-ryto.html#.Vx96cjCLTDe|title=BasketNews.lt|language=Lithuanian|date=21 April 2016|access-date=26 April 2016}}</ref>
[[Šarūnas Jasikevičius]], [[head coach]] of Lithuanian team [[BC Žalgiris]], argued that "playing in a FIBA tournament means taking a 20-year step back".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/backstage/229218/playing-in-a-fiba-tournament-means-taking-a-20-year-step-back|title=Playing in a FIBA tournament means taking a 20-year step back|publisher=Eurohoops|date=20 April 2016|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref>
=====Russia===== [[Andrei Kirilenko]], president of the [[Russian Basketball Federation]], requested the [[VTB United League]] to suspend the participation of all Russian teams in EuroCup. He also said the contract with VTB would be voided if the league refuses.<ref name="Lietuvos Rytas" />
=====Spain===== Francisco Roca, president of the [[Asociación de Clubs de Baloncesto|Spanish ACB]], said, "the ban is unfair and unfounded", and said that there is not any ban for Spanish teams from playing in FIBA competitions, despite agreeing to the contract with [[Euroleague Basketball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/euroleague/226706/roca-the-ban-is-unfair-and-unfounded|title=Roca: "The ban is unfair and unfounded"|publisher=Eurohoops|date=17 April 2016|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref>
The [[Spanish Basketball Federation]] (FEB) requested that the ACB suspend its agreement with the EuroLeague. The ACB answered again to the FEB, stating that it cannot impede Spanish clubs from joining their tournaments, and that the possible suspension of the [[Spanish national basketball team|Spanish national team]] was not its fault.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/baloncesto/basketfeb/2016/04/23/571aa447e5fdeaac628b4627.html|title=La ACB responde a la carta de la FEB|publisher=Marca|language=Spanish|date=23 April 2016|access-date=25 April 2016}}</ref>
On 13 May 2016, the [[Consejo Superior de Deportes|Supreme Council for Sports]] of Spain unilaterally cancelled the agreement between the ACB and EuroLeague, with the aim to avoid the suspension to the [[Spain national basketball team|men's national team]].<ref name="CSD anula">{{cite web|url=http://www.mundodeportivo.com/baloncesto/euroliga/20160513/401773619557/el-csd-anula-el-acuerdo-entre-la-acb-y-la-euroliga.html|publisher=Mundo Deportivo|language=Spanish|date=13 May 2016|title=Vía libre a la Selección: el CSD anula el acuerdo entre la ACB y la Euroliga|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref> The Clubs Association (ACB) regretted the action of the Council, arguing that it restricts the clubs' freedom to choose the competition that they want to play in. Also, it reminded that FIBA did not explain the reasons for the possible suspension.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acb.com/redaccion.php?id=122628|language=Spanish|date=13 May 2016|access-date=13 May 2016|title=Comunicado Oficial de la ACB|publisher=ACB.com}}</ref>
=====Slovenia===== The [[Slovenian Basketball Federation]], despite the possible suspension of [[Slovenian national basketball team|its national team]], supports FIBA in "its efforts to take action against ECA’s allegedly anti-competitive and illegal practices", but does not understand the suspension, as the Federation does not have any rights in the [[Adriatic League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/national-teams/national-teams/197520/slovenia-basketball-federation-replies-to-fiba-europe-calling-suspension-unfair-unfounded.html|title=Slovenia Basketball Federation replies to FIBA Europe calling suspension unfair, unfounded|publisher=Sportando|date=20 April 2016|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref>
===Suspension of the recognition of the ABA League=== On 13 April 2016, The [[ABA League]], comprising teams from the former [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]], agreed with EuroLeague on a four-year contract, for one EuroLeague and three EuroCup spots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tanjug.rs/full-view_en.aspx?izb=240934|title=ABA League gets one Euroleague, three Eurocup spots|publisher=Tanjug|date=13 April 2016|access-date=2 May 2016}}</ref>
Because of this agreement, FIBA threatened to suspend the six national federations with teams in the ABA League, and on 30 April 2016, it suspended its recognition of the ABA League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/coid_,xM3YrFJIck-c700Wd,Mn2.articleMode_on.html|title=FIBA Europe Executive Committee evaluates national federations' response and decides further steps|publisher=FIBA Europe|date=1 May 2016|access-date=2 May 2016}}</ref> This official recognition was in place since 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talkbasket.net/4064-adriatic-league-officially-recognised-by-fiba-europe.html|publisher=TalkBasket|title=Adriatic League officially recognised by FIBA Europe!|date=18 November 2009|access-date=2 May 2016}}</ref> Krešimir Novosel, director of the ABA League, said that he was unsure about FIBA's reasons for suspending recognition of the league, after the ABA had reformed its league to follow the criteria of the International Federation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talkbasket.net/20272-adriatic-league-director-kresimir-novosel-isnt-sure-what-fibas-problem-is.html|title=Adriatic League director Kresimir Novosel isn’t sure what FIBA’s problem is?|publisher=TalkBasket|date=1 May 2016|access-date=2 May 2016}}</ref>
===Collaboration proposals=== On 3 May 2016, EuroLeague presented a collaboration proposal to FIBA, with the integration of the International Federation into the EuroLeague governance, and the possibility of accepting the new playing windows schedule for the [[FIBA World Cup]] qualifying games as main points.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/6uvqb49fnxpsmsbr|title=Euroleague Basketball presents collaboration proposal to FIBA|date=3 May 2016|access-date=4 May 2016}}</ref>
Two days later, FIBA sent a letter to EuroLeague, requesting that they agree that FIBA's newly formed competition (the [[Basketball Champions League|Champions League]]) become the new European-wide second-tier competition, instead of the [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]], that they agree to the new FIBA [[national team]] calendar and make the necessary adjustments to its new playing windows schedule, and that they would agree on the future expansion of the EuroLeague to 24 teams in upcoming seasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/national-teams/national-teams/198834/fiba-still-open-to-dialogue-here-s-what-they-asked-to-euroleague.html|title=FIBA still open to dialogue, here's what they asked to Euroleague|date=5 May 2016|access-date=6 May 2016|publisher=Sportando}}</ref>
===Threats of suspension of teams===
====Israel==== On 28 June 2016, the [[Israel Basketball Association]] (IBA) informed that [[Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.|Hapoel Jerusalem]], which signed a contract to participate in the EuroCup, would not be allowed to register and play in the [[Israeli Basketball Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sport5.co.il/articles.aspx?FolderID=274&docID=218171&lang=HE|title=האיגוד הודיע לירושלים: לא תוכלו להירשם העונה לליגה|trans-title=|language=|author=|date=|website=Sport5.co.il - אתר ערוץ הספורט|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref> In response, [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]], one of the teams with an A-license to play in the EuroLeague, announced that, in that case, they would also refuse to register to the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sport5.co.il/articles.aspx?FolderID=274&docID=218151&lang=HE|date=28 June 2016|access-date=29 June 2016|language=Hebrew|publisher=Sport5|title=מכבי הודיעה: אם הפועל ירושלים בחוץ, גם אנחנו|trans-title=}}</ref> Ultimately, the IBA did not apply any sanction.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
====Italy==== On 22 April 2016, the three Italian teams that signed a contract with EuroLeague ([[Pallacanestro Reggiana|Reggio Emilia]], [[Dinamo Basket Sassari|Dinamo Sassari]] and [[Aquila Basket Trento]]) announced they would withdraw from the EuroCup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/cups/eurocup/197706/reggio-emilia-trento-and-sassari-to-withdraw-from-eurocup.html|title=Reggio Emilia, Trento and Sassari to withdraw from Eurocup?|publisher=Sportando|date=22 July 2016}}</ref> After several threats from [[FIBA]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/featured/270950/fiba-asking-from-national-federations-to-saction-eurocup-teams|title=FIBA asking from national federations to saction Eurocup teams|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=30 June 2016|access-date=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/featured/277134/italian-teams-withdraw-from-eurocup|title=Italian teams withdraw from Eurocup!|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=8 July 2016|access-date=21 July 2016}}</ref> they withdrew from the competition,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleaguebasketball.net/euroleague-basketball/news/i/75agarfis3mk4kro|title=Clubs from FYROM, Lithuania, Russia, Spain to replace Italian clubs in 2016-17 7DAYS EuroCup|publisher=Euroleague Basketball|date=21 July 2016|access-date=21 July 2016}}</ref> and instead joined the FIBA competition, the Basketball Champions League.
====Russia==== On 27 June 2016, just after participants of the 2016–17 EuroLeague and EuroCup Basketball were revealed, [[Andrei Kirilenko]], president of the [[Russian Basketball Federation]], announced that the four Russian participants in EuroCup ([[BC Khimki|Khimki]], [[PBC Lokomotiv Kuban|Lokomotiv Kuban]], [[BC Nizhny Novgorod|Nizhny Novgorod]], and [[BC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]]) would be disqualified from national domestic competitions (like the [[Russian Basketball Cup|Russian Cup]]), and that their players would be banned from playing with the [[Russia national basketball team|Russian national team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/europe/russia/203831/andrei-kirilenko-nizhny-khimki-lokomotiv-and-zenit-will-be-all-disqualified-.html|title=Andrei Kirilenko: 'Nizhny, Khimki, Lokomotiv and Zenit will be all disqualified'|publisher=Sportando|date=27 June 2016|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref> This does not affect participation in the [[VTB United League]], which is not organised by the Russian Federation.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
====Spain==== On 2 August 2016, [[Jorge Garbajosa]], recently elected as president of the [[Spanish Basketball Federation]], sent a letter to the six Spanish clubs that were registered in the EuroCup ([[Bilbao Basket|Bilbao]], [[Baloncesto Fuenlabrada|Fuenlabrada]], [[CB Gran Canaria|Gran Canaria]], [[Baloncesto Málaga|Málaga]], [[CB Murcia|Murcia]], and [[Valencia BC|Valencia]]), accusing them of violating the rules of Spain's [[Consejo Superior de Deportes|Supreme Council of Sports]]. This organisation of the [[Spanish government]] had previously cancelled the ACB-EuroLeague agreement.<ref name="CSD anula" />
====Greece==== The [[Hellenic Basketball Federation]] initially threatened to ban [[AEK Athens BC|AEK Athens]] from the [[Greek Basket League]], if it did not switch from the EuroCup to FIBA's Basketball Champions League. The Hellenic Basketball Federation stated that they were sent a letter by FIBA, that demanded that they make such threats. After AEK initially refused to switch to the Champions League, the Hellenic Basketball Federation then refused to grant any Greek League player licenses (meaning they could not play in the Greek League) for all of AEK's new summer signings,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/heba/288983/fiba-banned-aeks-new-players-from-getting-a-greek-license|title=FIBA banned AEK's new players from getting a Greek license - Eurohoops|author=|date=28 July 2016|website=Eurohoops.net|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref> if they remained in the EuroCup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/eurocup/298789/hapoel-jerusalem-stays-in-eurocup|title=Hapoel Jerusalem stays in Eurocup - Eurohoops|author=|date=14 August 2016|website=Eurohoops.net|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref> As a result of this, AEK had no other choice but to withdraw from the EuroCup and switch to the Champions League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/featured/296233/aek-leaves-eurocup-blames-both-euroleague-and-fiba|title=AEK leaves Eurocup, blames both Euroleague and FIBA - Eurohoops|author=|date=10 August 2016|website=Eurohoops.net|access-date=16 July 2017}}</ref>
===Expansion of the Basketball Champions League=== On 19 August 2016, FIBA announced the expansion of its Basketball Champions League to 40 teams in the regular season, after allowing [[AEK Athens B.C.|AEK Athens]], [[KK Partizan|Partizan]] and [[Basket Zielona Góra|Stelmet Zielona Góra]] to play in it. The three teams previously withdrew from the EuroCup, weeks after this competition had already established the groups and the calendar schedule of the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.basketballcl.com/16-17/news/aek-partizan-and-zielona-gora-join-basketball-champions-league-as-competition-expands|title=AEK, Partizan and Zielona Gora join Basketball Champions League as competition expands|access-date=19 August 2016|date=19 August 2016|publisher=BasketballCL.com}}</ref>
As consequence of this, the EuroCup reduced its competition to 20 teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gigantes.com/eurocup-de-20-equipos-el-fuenla-al-grupo-b-con-el-bilbao-y-el-skopje-al-a-con-el-granca/|title=Eurocup de 20 equipos: el Fuenla, al grupo B con el Bilbao, y el Skopje, al A con el Granca|trans-title=|publisher=GigantesBasket.com|date=19 September 2016|access-date=20 September 2016|language=es}}</ref>
===Return to threats of suspension of national teams=== In November 2016, [[FIBA]] sent new letters to the national federations from [[Basketball Federation of Slovenia|Slovenia]], [[Basketball Federation of Montenegro|Montenegro]] and [[Basketball Federation of Macedonia|Macedonia]] asking them to take measures against clubs which compete in the [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/fiba/344079|title=FIBA sent warnings to national federation again|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=12 November 2016|access-date=12 November 2016}}</ref> After this, The Montenegrin Federation suspended [[KK Budućnost|Budućnost VOLI]] from all domestic competitions due to their participation in EuroCup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/featured/353236|title=Buducnost temporary suspended from the Montenegrin Basketball Federation|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=26 November 2016|access-date=26 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/featured/348062|title="FIBA demonstrates the argument of power instead of the power of argument"|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=18 November 2016|access-date=18 November 2016}}</ref>
===Promotion from Basketball Champions League to EuroLeague=== In November 2016, [[FIBA]] returned to talk with [[Euroleague Basketball]] to express their wish to want a EuroLeague spot to the Champions League winner,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/featured/350904|title=FIBA wants a Euroleague spot for the Champions League winner|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=23 November 2016|access-date=23 November 2016}}</ref> but Euroleague Basketball CEO replied to FIBA’s proposal, because he understands that this would mean the jump from the European third division to the European first division in an attempt to finish with the EuroCup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/featured/355419|title=Italian clubs ready for Eurocup, Bertomeu throws the gauntlet|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=30 November 2016|access-date=30 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/cups/eurocup/218869/bertomeu-the-champions-league-winners-in-euroleague-impossible-and-it-doesn-t-make-any-sense.html|title=Bertomeu: The Champions League winners in EuroLeague? Impossible and it doesn't make any sense|publisher=Sportando|date=30 November 2016|access-date=30 November 2016}}</ref>
===Return of Italian, French and Turkish clubs to EuroCup=== In January 2017, the Italian clubs wanted to return EuroCup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/featured/383149|title=Italians return to Eurocup|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=15 January 2017|access-date=15 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/cups/eurocup/223119/italy-will-have-one-spot-in-euroleague-and-two-in-eurocup-next-season.html|title=Italy will have one spot in EuroLeague and two in EuroCup next season|publisher=Sportando|date=15 January 2017|access-date=15 January 2017}}</ref> In February 2017, the French clubs also wanted to return EuroCup, despite the wishes of the French basketball federation that is one of the most faithful supporters of Basketball Champions League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/eurocup/404128|title=The French clubs return to EuroCup and the 18-club EuroLeague|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=19 February 2017|access-date=19 February 2017}}</ref> In March 2017, the [[Italian Basketball Federation|Italian Federation]] said that it will give freedom to join any European competition from 2017–18 based on sports merit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/cups/eurocup/227869/italian-teams-to-compete-in-eurocup-again-from-next-season.html#refresh_ce|title=Italian teams to compete in EuroCup again from next season|publisher=Sportando|date=4 March 2017|access-date=4 March 2017}}</ref> Days later, the [[Turkish Basketball Federation]] made the same statement<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.basketeurope.com/livenews-fr/392143/__trashed-5/|title=Les clubs turcs pourront faire leur retour en Eurocup la saison prochaine|language=fr|date=13 March 2017|publisher=Basket Europe}}</ref> and French club [[ASVEL Basket]], chaired by NBA player [[Tony Parker]], confirmed it will join EuroCup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.basketeurope.com/livenews-fr/392166/lasvel-en-eurocup-la-saison-prochaine/|publisher=Basket Europe|language=fr|date=13 March 2017|title=L’ASVEL en Eurocup la saison prochaine}}</ref>
==National teams windows== For the [[2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup|2019 World Cup]], FIBA established a new qualification system, using six weekends during the 2017–18 and 2018–19 seasons, when the qualifiers will interrupt the club competitions. In May 2017, the [[National Basketball Association]] made a statement that the NBA teams will not loan their players to the national teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2707252-non-nba-players-to-make-up-team-usa-roster-for-2019-fiba-world-cup-qualifying|publisher=Bleacher Report|date=2 May 2017|access-date=16 May 2017|title=Non-NBA Players to Make Up Team USA Roster for 2019 FIBA World Cup Qualifying}}</ref> Days later, Euroleague Basketball's CEO [[Jordi Bertomeu]] made the same statement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurohoops.net/en/euroleague/448736/bertomeu-teams-already-decided-keep-calender/|publisher=Eurohoops.net|date=15 May 2017|access-date=16 May 2017|title=Bertomeu: “The teams have already decided to keep the same calender”}}</ref>
For the first window, the majority of European players that play in the [[2017–18 EuroLeague]] were called up for their national teams, but they all refused to join them.

revision.text:
The [[Hugo Award]]s, named after [[Hugo Gernsback]], are presented every year for the best [[science fiction]] or [[fantasy]] works and achievements of the previous year. Results are based on the ballots submitted by members of the [[World Science Fiction Society]]. {{Infobox convention | name = Chicon III, the 20th World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Congress Plaza Hotel|Pick-Congress Hotel]] | location = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | country = United States | first = August 31-September 3, 1962 | last = | organizer = | filing = Non-profit | attendance = ~730 | website = [http://www.chicon.org/ chicon.org] }} The '''20th World Science Fiction Convention''', also known unofficially as '''Chicon III''' (less frequently, '''Chicon II'''), was held August 31–September 3, 1962, at the [[Congress Plaza Hotel|Pick-Congress Hotel]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]], United States. Because the second [[Worldcon]] held in Chicago was officially called, in its publications, the 10th Annual World Science Fiction Convention (and once as the "10th Annual Science Fiction Convention") and not Chicon, the next Chicago Worldcon held in 1962 was occasionally referred to as Chicon II, though Chicon III is the generally accepted and preferred nomenclature. The chairman was [[Earl Kemp]]. The guest of honor was [[Theodore Sturgeon]]. The toastmaster was [[Wilson Tucker]]. Total attendance was approximately 730. Following the convention, [[Advent (publisher)|Advent:Publishers]] published ''The Proceedings: Chicon III'', edited by [[Earl Kemp]]. The book includes transcripts of lectures and panels given during the course of the convention and includes numerous photographs as well. Events at the convention included an address by [[Willy Ley]]. ==Events== During his Guest of Honor speech, Theodore Sturgeon expressed regret that Hugo Award winner [[Robert A. Heinlein]] could not attend. Heinlein, at that moment, walked into the ballroom, in a white tux, saying that Ted's regret for his nonattendance was premature. He went to the podium, and Sturgeon offered him a sip from a water glass, asking Heinlein to share water with him (a reference to ''Stranger in a Strange Land''.) Heinlein and Sturgeon shared water. Before the convention, in 1961, chairman [[Earl Kemp]] wrote to [[Isaac Asimov]] relaying that someone had jokingly suggested that Asimov deliver a pseudo-lecture on the theme "The Positive Power of Posterior Pinching" and offered that the convention would "furnish some suitable posteriors for demonstration purposes." Asimov responded, "I have no doubt I could give a stimulating talk that would stiffen the manly fiber of every one in the audience." However, he noted, "I will have to ask the permission of various people who are (or would be) concerned in the matter. If they say 'no', it will be 'no.'" The suggested pseudo-lecture did not occur. ==Awards== {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== *[[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[Stranger in a Strange Land]]'' by [[Robert A. Heinlein]] *[[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Fiction]]: the "Hothouse" series (collected as: ''[[The Long Afternoon of Earth]]'') by [[Brian W. Aldiss]] *[[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'' *[[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Ed Emshwiller]] *[[Hugo Award for Best Professional Magazine|Best Professional Magazine]]: ''[[Analog Science Fiction|Analog]]'' *[[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''[[Warhoon]]'', edited by [[Richard Bergeron (fan)|Richard Bergeron]] ===Other awards=== *[[Worldcon Special Award|Special Award]]: [[Cele Goldsmith]] for editing ''[[Amazing Stories]]'' and ''[[Fantastic (magazine)|Fantastic]]'' magazines *Special Award: [[Donald H. Tuck]] for ''[[The Handbook of Science Fiction and Fantasy]]'' *Special Award: [[Fritz Leiber]] and the [[Hoffman Electric Corporation]] for the use of science fiction in advertisements ==In fiction== [[S. M. Stirling]]'s 2008 [[alternate history]] novel ''[[In the Courts of the Crimson Kings]]'' begins with a prologue set at this convention, in which a group of the science fiction authors in attendance watch a television broadcast of an American [[space probe]] as it lands on an inhabited Mars. Those present include [[Frederik Pohl|Frederik]] and Carol Pohl, [[Poul Anderson]], [[H. Beam Piper]], Guest of Honor [[Theodore Sturgeon]], [[Jack Williamson]], [[Robert A. Heinlein|Robert]] and [[Virginia Heinlein]], [[Arthur C. Clarke]], [[Larry Niven]], [[Isaac Asimov]], [[L. Sprague de Camp|L. Sprague]] and [[Catherine Crook de Camp]], [[John W. Campbell]], [[Frank Herbert]], and [[Leigh Brackett]]. Heinlein mentions an idea for a novel about Mars he had had but set aside when "the preliminary orbital telescope reports" had come in. (In actual history the completed book, ''[[Stranger in a Strange Land]]'', won the [[Hugo Award for Best Novel]] at the convention.) The authors comment as the broadcast from the probe reveals a Martian canal and wildlife and then, startlingly, the arrival of human-like Martians in a "land ship" who haul the probe off. ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |first=Robert |last=Cromie |work=[[Chicago Daily Tribune]] |title=The By-stander |page=E6 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/573383452.html?dids=573383452:573383452&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI |date=September 16, 1962 |accessdate=March 12, 2011 |quote=Rocket expert Willy Ley zoomed in and out of town a few days ago [...] to address the 20th annual convention of the World Science Fiction Writers association.}} {{cite book |last=Kemp |first=Earl |title=The Proceedings: Chicon III |publisher=Advent:Publishers |year=1963}} {{cite book |last=Sturgeon |first=Theodore |chapter=Guest of Honor Speech |title=Worldcon Guest of Honor Speeches |editor1-first=Mike |editor1-last=Resnick |editor1-link=Mike Resnick |editor2-first=Joe |editor2-last=Siclari |editor2-link=Joe Siclari |publisher=[[ISFiC Press]] |year=2006 |pages=89–101}} {{cite web|first=Richard |last=Lynch |work=Fan History of the 1960s |title=Chapter Eight: Worldcons of the 1960s |url=http://www.smithway.org/history/chap8a.html |date=March 29, 1996 |accessdate=September 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927132045/http://www.smithway.org/history/chap8a.html |archivedate=September 27, 2011 |df= }} {{cite web |first=Stephanie |last=Zvan |authorlink=Stephanie Zvan|work=Almost Diamonds |title=We Don't Do That Anymore |url=http://freethoughtblogs.com/almostdiamonds/2012/09/09/we-dont-do-that-anymore/ |date=September 9, 2012 |accessdate=March 20, 2015}} }} ==External links== * {{cite web|url= http://www.chicon.org/docs/Chicon%203%20program.pdf |title=Chicon III program book }} * {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Redirect|Two States|other uses|Two-state (disambiguation){{!}}Two-state}} {{Infobox book | name = 2 States: The Story Of My Marriage | image = 2 States - The Story Of My Marriage.jpg | author = [[Chetan Bhagat]] | country = [[India]] | language = Hindi | genre = [[Fiction]], [[Love]] | publisher = Rupa Publications Pvt. Ltd | release_date = 8 October 2009 | media_type = NA | pages = 321 | isbn = 978-81-291-1530-0 | website = {{URL|http://www.chetanbhagat.com/books/2_states/}} }}
'''''2 States: The Story of My Marriage'''''<ref>{{cite web|title=Box Office: '2 States' rakes on Rs 70 cr|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/box-office-2-states-rakes-on-rs-70-cr/15257075|publisher=Mid Day|accessdate=28 April 2014|date=28 April 2014}}</ref> commonly known as '''''2 States<ref>{{cite news|last=Nagpal Tyagi|first=Shalu|title=Movie Review: '2 States'|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/movie-review-2-states/15238074|accessdate=25 April 2014|newspaper=Mid Day|date=18 April 2014}}</ref>''''' is a 2009 [[novel]] written by [[Chetan Bhagat]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=bhagat|first1=chetan|title=2 states|date=8 October 2009|publisher=haider ali}}</ref> It is the story about a couple coming from two different states in India, who face hardships in convincing their parents to approve of their marriage. Bhagat wrote this novel after quitting his job as an investment banker. This is his fourth book after ''[[Five Point Someone]]'', ''[[One Night @ the Call Center]]'' and ''[[The Three Mistakes of My Life]]''.
== Plot summary ==
2 States: The Story of My Marriage is partly autobiographical. The story is about a couple, Krish and Ananya, who fall from two different states of India, Punjab and Tamil Nadu respectively, are deeply in love and want to get married.
The story begins in the IIM Ahmedabad mess hall, where Krish, a Punjabi boy from Delhi sights a beautiful girl, Ananya, a Tamilian from Chennai, quarreling with the mess staff about the food. Ananya was tagged as the "Best girl of the fresher batch". They become friends within a few days and decide to study together every night. In the mean time, they become romantically involved. They both get jobs, and have serious plans for their wedding. At first Krish tries to convince his girlfriend Ananya's parents and at last convinces them by helping Ananya's father to do his first PowerPoint Presentation, her brother, Manju, by giving him IIT tuition and later convinces her mom by asking her to sing in a concert organised by Krish's off City at CitiBank. She is convinced as her biggest dream of singing at a big concert comes true. Then they try to convince Krish's mom. But the problem is Krish's mother's relatives who don't quite like this. They say that Krish should not marry a Tamilian but end up agreeing with them when Ananya tries to help one of Krish's cousin to get married and succeeds to do so. Krish has had a hatred on his father. He never shares his feelings or doesn't share a harmonious bonding with him. Now as they have convinced both their parents they now try to introduce each other's parents. They go to Goa. But this dream of theirs end as Ananya's parents finds something fishy between Krish's mom and him. Ananya's family end up deciding that Krish and Ananya will not marry each other. Krish started becoming workaholic and started living badly. But, at last, Krish's father, who was like an enemy for Krish, helps Krish and Ananya to get married as he convinces Ananya's family well. Now Krish realizes his Dad's love for him. They really do very hard to convince each other's parents and finally make it. It is narrated in a first person point of view in a humorous tone, often taking digs at both Tamil and Punjabi cultures . The novel ends with Ananya giving birth to twin boys. He says that the babies belong to a state called 'India'; with a thought to end inequality.
==Film adaptation== {{main|2 States (film)}} When a film adaptation of the novel was first announced, it was to be directed by [[Siddharth Anand]] and the lead roles were played by [[Arjun Kapoor]] and [[Alia Bhatt]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/1245384/Saif--Priyanka-in-Siddharth-Anands-adaptation-of-Chetan-Bhagats-2-States|title=Saif & Priyanka in Siddharth Anand's adaptation of Chetan Bhagat's '2 States' {{!}} Bollywood News {{!}} Hindi Movies News {{!}} News - BollywoodHungama.com|last=Hungama|first=Bollywood|website=Bollywood Hungama|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref> The music to be composed by [[Vishal Shekhar|Vishal-Shekhar]]. However, the project was called off due to creative differences over script.
Later, it was announced that the screen adaptation of 2 States would be produced by [[Sajid Nadiadwala]] with [[Shahrukh Khan]] and Priyanka Chopra in the lead roles and [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] would be directing the movie.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news-interviews/Shah-Rukh-Khan-Priyanka-Chopra-re-ignite-2-States/articleshow/8960147.cms|title=Shah Rukh Khan, Priyanka Chopra re-ignite 2 States | newspaper=Times of India|date=23 June 2011|first=Subhash K|last=Jha|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref>
However, since Shahrukh Khan did not want to appear in back to back romantic movies, the director had to look at other options. It was later declared that [[Imran Khan (Bollywood actor)|Imran Khan]] will be playing the male lead in the movie. But then, due to clash of dates, Imran and Priyanka had to opt out of the movie as well. After a lot of brainstorming, it was finally confirmed by producers [[Karan Johar]] and [[Sajid Nadiadwala]] that [[Arjun Kapoor]] and [[Alia Bhatt]] will be seen playing the lead pair in the movie. [[Amrita Singh]] and [[Ronit Roy]] were cast as Arjun Kapoor's parents and [[Revathy]] and [[Shiv Kumar Subramaniam]] were cast as Alia Bhatt's parents.
This movie was released on 18 April 2014.

revision.text: {{italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = A Second Knock at the Door | image = | alt = | caption = | film name = | director = [[Christopher Grimes]] | producer = | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = | released = {{film date|2011}} | runtime = | country = | language = | budget = | gross = }} '''''A Second Knock at the Door''''' is a documentary on [[friendly fire]] in [[Iraq]] and [[Afghanistan]].[http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/42228/ A Second Knock at the Door] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193741/http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/42228/ |date=October 29, 2013 }}, ''Film Threat'' The film follows military families after they are told their family member died in a "fratricide" incident. All the families profiled in the film only learned their family member was killed by a comrade, not an enemy, months after they first learned of their death. Director [[Christopher Grimes]] has described being inspired by the official coverup of former sport star [[Pat Tillman]] being killed by his comrades. The film was screened at the [[Flyway Film Festival]] in 2011, and the [[East Lansing Film Festival]] in 2012. ==Notes== {{cite news | url = http://asp.militarygear.com/2012/03/28/a-second-knock-at-the-door/ | title = A Second Knock at the Door | publisher = [[A Soldier's Perspective]] | author = | date = 2012-03-28 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140212073617/http://asp.militarygear.com/2012/03/28/a-second-knock-at-the-door/ | archivedate=2014-02-12 | accessdate = 2014-02-12 | deadurl = No | quote = For Christopher E. Grimes, then a graduate student planning his Master’s thesis in Public Policy at Northwestern University, the case provoked the question: how many other cases like Pat Tillman’s are there? The results of Grimes’ thesis research is the award-winning documentary feature A SECOND KNOCK AT THE DOOR, which shares the heart-breaking stories of four families who have lost loved ones due to friendly fire. }} {{cite news | url = http://qctimes.com/entertainment/columnists/linda-cook/documentaries-to-help-pass-a-cabin-fever-weekend/article_1990fa8c-8b25-5c19-8777-c0181b8d0029.html | title = 33 documentaries to help pass a cabin fever weekend | publisher = [[Quad City Times]] | author = Linda Cook | date = 2014-02-01 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fqctimes.com%2Fentertainment%2Fcolumnists%2Flinda-cook%2Fdocumentaries-to-help-pass-a-cabin-fever-weekend%2Farticle_1990fa8c-8b25-5c19-8777-c0181b8d0029.html&date=2014-02-12 | archivedate = 2014-02-12 | accessdate = 2014-02-12 | deadurl = No | quote = Loved ones of those in the military who lost their lives to “friendly fire” are interviewed about what really happened to cause the deaths. }} {{cite news | url = http://www.pretentiousfilm.com/2012/02/showcase-spotlight-second-knock-at-door.html | title = Showcase Spotlight: "A Second Knock at the Door," with Q & A, Screening Saturday, 2/18 | publisher = [[Pretentious Film Society]] | author = | date = 2012-02-11 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121204175625/http://www.pretentiousfilm.com/2012/02/showcase-spotlight-second-knock-at-door.html | archivedate = 2012-12-04 | accessdate = 2014-02-12 | deadurl = No | quote = When I saw A SECOND KNOCK AT THE DOOR, at last year's Flyway Film Festival, I was completely knocked off my feet. This is a powerful documentary which focuses on the issue of American troop fatalities caused by "friendly fire," which is the inadvertent firing on one's own soldiers while engaging with an enemy. }} {{cite news | url = http://live.hollywoodjesus.com/?p=9892 | title = Friendly Fire, Unfriendly Lies | publisher = [[Hollywood Jesus]] | author = Brian Dedmon | date = 2012-03-29 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120404131501/http://live.hollywoodjesus.com/?p=9892 | archivedate = 2012-04-04 | accessdate = 2014-02-12 | deadurl = No | quote = The title, A Second Knock At The Door, is a tell-tale application of the emotions involved in these family’s experiences. After being told that their soldier was killed by mortar fire from an enemy or a car accident they discover, most often months later, that their kin was killed by friendly fire. In some cases the army went to great lengths to cover up the exact details of how the {{sic|solider}} was killed. It is alarming to consider that the U.S. Army would lie about a soldier’s death to save face, but they’re only human. }} {{cite news | url = http://www.lansingcitypulse.com/lansing/article-6572-east-lansing-film-festival-special.html | title = East Lansing Film Festival Special | publisher = [[East Lansing City Pulse]] | author = | date = 2012-05-31 | page = | location = | isbn = | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130419224204/http://www.lansingcitypulse.com/lansing/article-6572-east-lansing-film-festival-special.html | archivedate = 2013-04-19 | accessdate = 2014-02-12 | deadurl = No | quote = To the government, friendly fire incidents are embarrassing blunders that needn’t be dwelled upon; to the families, the fog and secrecy surrounding their loved ones’ deaths make the pain of loss even worse. }} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1954214}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Second Knock At The Door, A}} [[Category:Documentary films about war]] [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Friendly fire incidents]] {{war-documentary-film-stub}}

{{Redirect|The Age of Revolution|the book|The Age of Revolution: Europe 1789–1848}}
[[File:Storming the bastille 4 - 2.jpg|thumb|French Revolution]] [[File:Washington Crossing the Delaware by Emanuel Leutze, MMA-NYC, 1851.jpg|thumb|American Revolution]] [[File:MAXWELL(1845) p089 Murder of George Crawford.jpg|thumb|Irish Rebellion]]
The '''Age of Revolution''' is the period from approximately 1774 to 1849 in which a number of significant [[revolution]]ary movements occurred in many parts of Europe and the [[Americas]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Matson, Cathy|title=The Atlantic Economy in an Era of Revolutions: An Introduction|publisher=William and Mary Quarterly|date=July 2005}}</ref> The period is noted for the change in government from [[Absolutism (European history)|absolutist monarchies]] to [[constitutionalist|constitutionalist states]] and [[republic]]s. The Age of Revolution includes the [[American Revolution]], the [[French Revolution]], the [[Irish Rebellion of 1798]], the [[Haitian Revolution]], the revolt of [[slave]]s in [[Latin America]], the [[First Italian War of Independence]], [[Sicilian revolution of 1848]], and the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Italian states|1848 revolutions in Italy]]; and the independence movements of Spanish and Portuguese colonies in Latin America. In a way, it includes the [[Industrial Revolution]]. The period would generally weaken the [[imperialism|imperialist]] European states, who would lose major assets throughout the [[New World]]. For the [[Kingdom of Great Britain|British]], the loss of the [[Thirteen Colonies]] would bring a [[British Empire#Rise of the "Second" British Empire (1783–1815)|change in direction]] for the [[British Empire]], with [[Asia]] and the [[Pacific]] becoming new targets for expansion.
The expression was popularised by the British historian [[Eric Hobsbawm]] in his book ''[[The Age of Revolution: Europe 1789–1848]].''<ref>Hobsbawm, Eric, ''The Age of Revolution: Europe 1789–1848'', London, Abacus (1962). </ref>
==Industrial Revolution== {{Main|Industrial Revolution}} The Industrial Revolution was the transition to new manufacturing processes in the period from about 1760 to sometime between 1820 and 1840. It marked a major turning point in history and almost every aspect of daily life was influenced in some way. In particular, average income and population began to exhibit unprecedented sustained growth. This led to the expansion of cities that was so rapid, it resulted in social strains and disturbances.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Theory of Collective Behavior|last=Smelser|first=Neil|publisher=Quid Pro Books|year=2011|isbn=9781610270854|location=New Orleans|pages=311}}</ref> For instance, economic grievances associated with this industrialization fed later revolutions such as those that transpired from 1848.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Industrial Revolution: Steam and Steel|last=Wolfe|first=James|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|year=2015|isbn=9781680480283|location=New York|pages=85}}</ref> New social classes emerged including those that began to reject orthodox politics.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Industrial Revolution|last=Hudson|first=Pat|publisher=Hodder Arnold|year=1992|isbn=9780713165319|location=New York|pages=35}}</ref> This is demonstrated by the rise of the urban [[middle class]], which became a powerful force so that they had to be integrated into the political system.<ref>{{Cite book|title=From Empire to Europe: The Decline and Revival of British Industry Since the Second World War|last=Owens|first=Geoffrey|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|year=2017|isbn=9780006387503|location=London|pages=}}</ref> The upheavals also led to new political ideas that were directed against the social arrangements of the preindustrial regime.<ref name=":0" />
==American Revolution (1775–1783)== {{Main|American Revolution}} The [[Thirteen Colonies]] of British America famously became independent in the [[American Revolution]] of 1776. The movement was the first European colony to claim independence and saw the application of elected government, a constitution, and limited civil rights, none of which were unheard of but were unique in their combination. This was the birth of the United States of America.
==French Revolution (1789–1799)== {{Main|French Revolution}} The French Revolution was a period of radical social and political upheaval in France from 1789 to 1799 that profoundly affected French and modern history, marking the decline of powerful monarchies and churches and the rise of democracy and nationalism. Popular resentment of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and aristocracy grew amidst an economic crisis following two expensive wars and years of bad harvests, motivating demands for change. These were couched in terms of Enlightenment ideals and caused the convocation of the Estates-General in May 1789.
==Haitian Revolution (1791–1804)== {{Main|Haitian Revolution}} The Haitian Revolution was a slave revolt in the French colony of Saint-Domingue, which culminated in the elimination of slavery there and the founding of the Republic of Haiti. The Haitian Revolution was the only slave revolt which led to the founding of a state. Furthermore, it is generally considered the most successful slave rebellion ever to have occurred and as a defining moment in the histories of both Europe and the Americas. The rebellion began with a revolt of black African slaves in August 1791. It ended in November 1803 with the French defeat at the battle of Vertières. Haiti became an independent country on January 1, 1804.
==United Irishmen Rebellion (1798)== {{Main|Irish Rebellion of 1798}} In 1798, Irishmen rose against British Rule in Ireland in the hopes of creating a Republic. The rebellion was initiated by the Society of United Irishmen and led by Theobald Wolfe Tone. They rebelled against the government for a number of reasons but most notably due to the sectarian nature of British Rule, which upheld the Penal Laws that discrimated against Catholics and Presbyterians in Irish society. The rebellion failed and led to the Act of Union in 1801.
== Serbian Revolution (1804–1835) == {{Main|Serbian Revolution}} The Serbian Revolution was a national uprising and constitutional change in [[Serbia]] that took place between 1804 and 1835, during which the territory evolved from an [[Belgrade Pashaluk|Ottoman province]] into a rebel territory, a [[Constitution of Serbia|constitutional monarchy]], and finally the modern Serbian state. The first part of the period, from 1804 to 1815, was marked by a violent struggle for independence from the [[Ottoman Empire]] with two armed uprisings taking place, ending with a ceasefire. During the later period (1815–1835) a peaceful consolidation of political power developed in the increasingly autonomous Serbia, culminating in the recognition of the right to hereditary rule by [[List of Serbian monarchs|Serbian princes]] in 1830 and 1833 and the territorial expansion of the young monarchy. The adoption of the first written [[Constitution of Serbia|Constitution]] in 1835 abolished [[feudalism]] and [[serfdom]], and made the country [[Suzerainty|suzerain]]. The term "Serbian Revolution" was coined by a German academic historiographer, [[Leopold von Ranke]], in his book ''Die Serbische Revolution'', published in 1829. These events marked the foundation of the modern [[Principality of Serbia]].
Scholars have characterized the Serbian War of Independence and subsequent national liberation as a revolution because the uprisings were started by broad masses of rural Serbian people who were in severe class conflict with the Turkish landowners as a political and economic masters at the same time, similar to [[Greek War of Independence|Greece in 1821–1832]].{{cn|date=February 2018}}
==Latin American Wars of Independence (1808–1833)== {{Main|Spanish American wars of independence|War of Independence of Brazil}}
Latin America experienced [[Spanish American wars of independence|independence revolutions]] in the early 19th century that separated the colonies from [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]], creating new nations. These movements were generally led by the ethnically Spanish but locally born [[Creole people|Creole]] class; these were often wealthy citizens that held high positions of power but were still poorly respected by the European-born Spaniards. One such Creole was [[Simón Bolívar]], who led several revolutions throughout South America and helped establish [[Gran Colombia]]. Another important figure was [[José de San Martín]], who helped create the [[United Provinces of Rio de la Plata]] and became the first president of [[Peru]]. Some Latin American revolts, such as the Haitian Revolution, were led by slaves.
==Greek War of Independence (1821–1832)== {{Main|Greek War of Independence}} Greece in the early part of the 1800s was under the rule of the Ottoman Empire. A series of revolts, starting in 1821, began the conflict. The Ottoman Empire sent in forces to suppress the revolts. By 1827, forces from Russia, Great Britain, and France entered the conflict, helping the Greeks drive the Turkish forces off the Peloponnese Peninsula. The Turks finally recognized Greece as a free nation in May 1832.
==Revolutions of 1820== {{main|Revolutions of 1820}}
==Revolutions of 1830== {{main|Revolutions of 1830}}
==Revolutions of 1848== {{Main|Revolutions of 1848}} The European Revolutions of 1848, known in some countries as the Spring of Nations, Springtime of the Peoples or the Year of Revolution, were a series of political upheavals throughout Europe in 1848. It remains the most widespread revolutionary wave in European history, but within a year, reactionary forces had regained control, and the revolutions collapsed.
The political impact of the 1848 revolutions was more evident in Austria in comparison to the revolution's effects in countries like Germany. This is attributed to the way the upheavals in Vienna resulted in greater loss of life and gained stronger support from intellectuals, students, and the working class.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The 1848 Revolutions in German-Speaking Europe|last=Hahn|first=Hans Joachim|publisher=Routledge|year=2014|isbn=9780582357655|location=Oxon|pages=107}}</ref> An account described the German experience as less concerned with national issues, although it succeeded in breaking down class barriers.<ref name=":1" /> There was a previously prevalent view that there was only one revolutionary event in Germany but recent scholarship pointed to a fragmented picture of several revolutions happening at the same time.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Revolutions in Europe, 1848-1849: From Reform to Reaction|last=Evans|first=Robert John|last2=von Strandmann|first2=Hartmut Pogge|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2002|isbn=0199249970|location=Oxford|pages=132}}</ref>
The 1848 revolutions were also notable because of the increased participation of women. While women rarely participated in revolutionary activities, there were those who performed supportive and auxiliary roles such as the cases of the women's political club in [[Vienna]], which demanded revolutionary measures from the Austrian Constituent Assembly, and the Parisian women who protested and proposed their own solutions to social problems, particularly those involving their rights and crafts.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The European Revolutions, 1848-1851|last=Sperber|first=Jonathan|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2005|isbn=0521839076|location=Cambridge|pages=188}}</ref>
==Eureka Rebellion (1856)== {{Main|Eureka Rebellion}} The Eureka Rebellion was a 20 minute shootout between the Miners of Ballarat, Victoria, against the British Redcoats. After the imposition of Gold Mining Licences, that being that a person had one of these to mine gold, and which costed 30 shillings a month to own a license, the miners decided that it was to much. So the Ballarat Miners started rallies at Bakery Hill and burnt their licenses, took an oath under the flag of the Southern Cross, elected Peter Lalor as their rebellion leader, and built a stockade (a makeshift fort) around the diggings. Eventually the Redcoats led by Governor Hotham of Ballarat fired upon the stockade. The miners fired back and lasted 20 minutes before being overthrown by the Redcoats. Most of the miners were arrested by the British, and taken to trial. If found guilty, they would hang for high treason. Even though it lasted only 20 minutes, it was the beginning of Democracy for all Australians.
==Taiping Revolution (1850-1864)== {{Main|Taiping Rebellion}} The Taiping Rebellion was a revolt against the [[Qing dynasty]] in China, fought with religious conviction over regional economic conditions, and lasting from 1850 to 1864. The Taiping forces were run as a cult-like group called the God Worshipping Society by self-proclaimed prophet [[Hong Xiuquan]], and resulted in the rebels seizing the city of [[Nanjing]] for a decade. The Taiping Rebellion eventually failed, however, and led to the deaths of more than 20 million people.
== See also == * [[List of revolutions and rebellions]] * [[Atlantic Revolutions]] * [[American Revolution]] * [[French Revolution]] * [[Haitian Revolution]] * [[Modern history]] * [[Long nineteenth century]] * [[Industrial Revolution]] * [[Risorgimento]] * [[Paris Commune]] (1871)

{{More citations needed|date=April 2011}} The '''Cine Las Americas International Film Festival''' is an annual [[film festival]] based in [[Austin, Texas]] featuring Latin American and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] films from the Americas. In its 14th year in 2011, the Festival has grown into a citywide event, with over 100 screenings in a nine-day span. Patrons of the festival are offered a wide variety of films to choose from including narrative and documentary features, short films, animation and youth films.[http://www.persistenceofvision.org/2010/10/14th-cine-las-americas-international-film-festival-deadline-january-14/ 14th Cine Las Americas International Film Festival Call for Entries], ''Persistence of Vision'', Journal of the Austin Film Society, AFS Communications Dept., 2010-10-06.[http://www.originalalamo.com/Signature.aspx?id=78 Cine Las Americas Film Festival]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Alamo Drafthouse Cinema, 2011. Retrieved 2011-04-10. ==Organization== Cine Las Americas, a [[501(c)#501.28c.29.283.29|501(c)(3)]] non-profit organization, is a [[Multiculturalism|multicultural]] organization that offers cultural experiences and business opportunities for Latinos in film and media arts, and brings media arts education to minority youth in Austin. While the international film festival seeks to become an institution in the international film business and trade, fostering multi-national film production, and accessing emerging markets and diverse audiences, Cine Las Americas remains a community oriented Media Arts Center, offering diverse opportunities for culture, education and fun.[http://cinelasamericas.org/about/about_history.html About Us, History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621184404/http://www.cinelasamericas.org/about/about_history.html |date=2009-06-21 }}, Cine Las Americas. Retrieved 2011-04-11. The Organization and History sections of this article are sourced from Cine Las Americas with their [http://www.cinelasamericas.org/wikipedia permission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725172018/http://cinelasamericas.org/wikipedia |date=2011-07-25 }}. ==Festival history== The Cine Las Americas International Film festival began in 1997 as a Cuban film [[retrospective]] sponsored by the [[Mexic-Arte Museum]] in [[Austin, Texas]]. While programming the initial event, the organizers realized that although Austin was building its reputation as an important city for producing and showcasing independent film, films made by and about Latinos were largely absent from the community's [[cultural landscape]]. In 2001, Cine Las Americas partnered with the [[Austin Independent School District]] (AISD) and moved the organization's offices to [[Johnston High School]] in East Austin, where it established a Media Arts Center, implementing educational and mentoring programs to support the District's Dropout Prevention Campaign. During this time the organization offered the school's students hands-on [[Multilingualism|bilingual]] opportunities in [[multimedia]] production, event production, and non-profit organization management. ===Festival-related programs and milestones=== The training students received in the Cine Las Americas-school district partnership culminated in students producing ''Emergencia'', the youth component of the film festival. In ''Emergencia'' they receive entries from around the country, preview them in order to [[Curator|curate]] a program, grant awards for the best work, and produce a day of free screenings within the context of the festival. ''Emergencia'' remains a special competitive section of the festival open to filmmakers ages 19 and under and is [[Curator|curated]] by students participating in Cine Las Americas' multicultural Media Literacy programs. In 2003, professional musicians and other guest artists began to instruct and [[Mentorship|mentor]] dozens of students at a [[recording studio]] inside the organization's classroom at the school. There, students were able to write and record music and lyrics in a professional studio environment within a bilingual Digital Music Production [[curriculum]] in the after-school program ''BeatLab''. Many students have used skills learned there in preparing work for subsequent Festivals. ''BeatLab'' has continued at other area schools since the organization's offices moved to East Austin after its contract with the school expired. Also in 2003, the festival extended its program to include indigenous work from the Americas, established competitive sections granting [[Juried (competition)|juried]] and audience awards. By 2005, the organization had presented more than 300 films at the annual Festival and at various screenings throughout Texas, collaborating with institutions such as The [[Museum of Fine Arts, Houston]] (MFAH), the [[South By Southwest]] film festival (SXSW), and the [[Austin Film Festival]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20100510003612/http://www.austinfilmfestival.com/new/31_minutes AFF & Cine Las Americas International Film Festival Present...31 MINUTES], Austin Film Festival, 2009. In 2007, the Festival expanded to its current format in celebration of Cine Las Americas' 10th anniversary. The 13th annual Cine Las Americas International Film Festival was held April 21–29, 2010, and featured [[Mexico]] as the invited country in celebration of Mexico's [[Celebration of Mexican political anniversaries in 2010|bicentennial]]. ===2009 awards=== Jury Award for Best Narrative Feature: El truco del manco (The Handless Trick) Director: [[Santiago Zannou]], [[Spain]], 2008 Jury Award for Best Documentary Feature: Intimidades de Shakespeare y Víctor Hugo (Shakespeare and Victor Hugo’s Intimacies) Director: Yulene Olaizola, [[Mexico]], 2008 Special Jury Award for Documentary Feature: Unidad 25 (Unit 25) Director: Alejo Hoijman, [[Argentina]] / [[Spain]], 2008 Jury Award for Best Narrative Short Film: Danzak Director: Gabriela Yepes, [[Peru]] / USA, 2008[http://rtf.utexas.edu/news/rtf-students-triumph-12th-cine-las-americas-international-film-festival RTF students triumph at the 12th Cine Las Americas International Film Festival], Univ of Texas at Austin, College of Communication, Radio, Television and Film Department, 2009-05-04. Special Jury Award for Narrative Short Film: Saliva Director: Esmir Filho, [[Brazil]], 2007 Jury Award for Best Documentary Short Film: Conversations II Director: Marianela Vega Oroza, Peru / USA, 2007 Audience Award for Best Narrative Feature: Cinco días sin Nora (Nora's Will) Director: [[Mariana Chenillo]], Mexico, 2008 Audience Award for Best Documentary Feature: El General Director: Natalia Almada, Mexico, 2009 Emergencia Youth Competition, Jury Award for Best Film: Journeys Through the Red, White and Blue: Brian's Journey Andrea Williams, USA, 2008 ===2008 awards=== JURY AWARD WINNERS: Jury Award for Best First or Second Narrative Feature NOEL POETA DA VILA (NOEL, THE SAMBA POET), Ricardo van Steen, Brazil, 2006 Jury Award for Best Narrative Short MEXICAN DREAM, David Michan, Mexico, 2007 Special Jury Mention for Narrative Short EN TRÁNSITO (IN TRANSIT), Isabel Muñoz Cota Callejas, México, 2007 Jury Award for Best Documentary Feature [[La Americana|LA AMERICANA]] (THE AMERICAN), Nicholas Bruckman, USA, 2008 Special Jury Mention for Documentary Feature LOS PUÑOS DE UNA NACIÓN (THE FISTS OF A NATION), Pituka Ortega Heilbron, Panama, 2006 Jury Award for Best Documentary Short CON EL TOQUE DE LA CHAVETA (WITH A STROKE OF THE CHAVETA), [[Pam Sporn|Pamela Sporn]], Cuba, USA, 2007 Special Jury Mention for Documentary Short POR MIS HIJOS (FOR THEM), Aymée Cruzalegui, Spain, 2007 AUDIENCE AWARD WINNERS: Audience Award for Best Narrative Feature NAO POR ACASO (NOT BY CHANCE), Philippe Barcinski, Brazil, Drama, 2007 Audience Award for Best Documentary Feature LA AMERICANA (THE AMERICAN), Nicholas Bruckman, USA, 2008 ===Earlier winners=== Best Documentary Feature 2006: De NADIE, Tin Dirdamal, 2006
De NADIE went on to win many other awards including the Audience Award, Sundance Film Festival 2006, and Mexican Ariele award for Best Feature Documentary, 2006.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070107000236/http://www.lasamericasfilms.org/ImmigrationSP07.htm Immigration Film Series], Las Américas Film Network. Retrieved 2011-04-10. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.cinelasamericas.org/film-festival Festival official site] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/CineLasAmericas Festival videos] on [[YouTube]] [[Category:Festivals in Austin, Texas]] [[Category:Film festivals in Texas]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American culture in Austin, Texas]] [[Category:Indigenous film festivals]] [[Category:Indigenous culture in the United States]] [[Category:Latin American film festivals]]
