{{more footnotes|date=January 2013}} [[File:Start zum Red Bull Dolomitenmann.jpg|thumb|Start of the 19th Dolomitenmann in 2006]] The '''Dolomitenmann''' is an [[extreme sports]] [[relay race]] held in September in the [[East Tyrol|East Tyrolean]], or [[Dolomites|Dolomite]] Mountains of [[Austria]], near the city of [[Lienz]]. The founder and organiser is [[Werner Grissmann]], a former [[FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|World Cup skier]]. The Dolomitenmann relay race has been run annually since 1988. In recent years the race has been sponsored by the manufacturers of [[Red Bull]] energy drink and is now known as ''Red Bull Dolomitenmann''. The race is billed by its organizers as "the world's toughest team relay race". == Disciplines == * [[File:Mountain running pictogram.svg|17px|link=fell running]] [[fell running|mountain running]] * [[File:Paragliding pictogram.svg|17px|link=paragliding]] [[paragliding]] * [[File:Cycling (mountain biking) pictogram.svg|17px|link=mountainbiking]] [[mountainbiking]] * [[File:Canoeing_(slalom)_pictogram.svg|17px|link=whitewater kayaking]] [[whitewater kayaking]] == Course == The race is started by the ''mountain runner'' on the town square of Lienz at {{convert|674|m|ft|}} above sea level. who then runs a distance of around {{convert|12|km|mi}} up to ''Kühbodentörl'' at {{convert|2441|m|ft|}}.{{citation | url=http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/racebook_berglauf_d_2016.pdf | title=Racebook Berglauf 2016 | trans-title=Racebook mountain running 2016 | accessdate=2016-11-28 | language=de | format=PDF | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128195938/http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/racebook_berglauf_d_2016.pdf | archivedate=2016-11-28 | df= }} When the runner makes the hand-off to the team’s ''paraglider'', he must also run, this time with his whole equipment to the first take-off point. After descending by air to Moosalm, the paraglider runs to a second take-off point, descending to Leisach where the ''mountain biker'' is ready and waiting.{{citation | url=http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/racebook_paragleiten_d_2016.pdf | title=Racebook Paragleiten 2016 | trans-title=Racebook paragliding 2016 | accessdate=2016-11-28 | language=de | format=PDF | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128200348/http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/racebook_paragleiten_d_2016.pdf | archivedate=2016-11-28 | df= }} The ''mountain biker'' typically climbs {{convert|1600|m|ft|}} or more, over a distance of about {{convert|27|km|mi}}. After the climb, the mountain biker must ride a downhill track to the finish.{{citation | url=http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/racebook_bike_d_2016.pdf | title=Racebook Mountainbike 2016 | accessdate=2016-11-28 | language=de | format=PDF | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128195733/http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/racebook_bike_d_2016.pdf | archivedate=2016-11-28 | df= }} The teams ''kayaker'' swims across the river [[Drau]] where his boat is stationed. His first maneuver is an "alpine-start", or a drop off a {{convert|7|m|ft}} ramp into the river. After the jump the ''kayaker'' must navigate a difficult white water track on the river {{ill|Isel (river)|lt=Isel|de|Isel}} before a last sprint back to the main square of Lienz.{{citation | url=http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/racebook_kajak_d.pdf | title=Racebook Kajak 2016 | trans-title=Racebook whitewater kayak 2016 | accessdate=2016-11-28 | language=de | format=PDF | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128200211/http://www.redbulldolomitenmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/racebook_kajak_d.pdf | archivedate=2016-11-28 | df= }} == Winning teams and tracks == {| |valign="top"| {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#cccccc" ! # !! {{more footnotes|date=January 2015}} '''Elephant Festival''' is a festival celebrated in [[Jaipur]] city in [[Rajasthan]] state in [[India]]. It is held on the day of [[Holi]] festival, usually in the month of March. The festival features [[Elephant polo]] and Elephant Dance. The Elephant Festival begins with a beautiful procession of bedecked elephants, [[camel]]s, [[horse]]s and [[Folk dance in India|folk dancers]]. The owners proudly embellish their elephants with vibrant colours, ''jhools'' (saddle cloth) and heavy jewellery. It is quite a treat to see female elephants wearing anklets, which tinkle as they walk. One can see people sprinkling 'gulaal' (coloured powder) perched on top of the elephant. The most beautifully decorated elephant is awarded. Elephant polo, Elephant race, the tug-of-war between Elephants and 19 men and women are the featured events of the festival. The elephants are also outfitted in ear danglers and brocade scarves to embellish their ears and necks. The [[Mahout]]s, who are known as the caretakers of the elephants, decorate the foreheads of the animals with head-plates as well as garnish their tusks with gold, silver bracelets and rings. Other events that take place during the festival include a polo match and a tug of war contest, where the strongest elephant is chosen to compete against a group of ten people.
Although the festival is primarily based on elephants, other animals such as camels and horses also participate in the elephant festival.
==History==
The Elephant Festival is considered one of the most popular and celebrated events in the city of Jaipur. Since the festival was introduced, the ceremony has managed to attract a variety of outsiders to the festive event. Elephants symbolize royalty according to the traditions of Rajasthan. The Elephant is also believed to be associated with [Buddhism] and [Jainism]. In fact, the elephant itself has a historical significance in Indian traditions. According to Indian Mythology, gods and the demons stirred the ocean, in the hopes that they would become eternal. Suddenly, nine jewels also known as the “navratnas” surfaced from the ocean. Of the nine jewels that reappeared, one of them was an elephant. Since then, the elephant has been regarded as a precious animal.
The state of Rajasthan was a popular destination for many royal figures as the kings and princes of those times would take elephant rides to the Amber Palace of Rajasthan. During the [monarchy], India’s royalty would hold events where the strongest elephants would fight each other to entertain the royal guests. Nowadays, the festival is organized every year by the Rajasthan tourism group in the [[Chaugan Stadium]]. The venue was relocated to the Jaipur Polo Group grounds due to the festival’s increasing popularity.
==Controversy==
For its first time in many years, the elephant festival was cancelled for two consecutive years, 2012 and 2014, due to protest from the [Animal Welfare Board of India|Animal Welfare Board]. The animal activists were concerned about the chemical-laced colour being mocked down on the elephants and feared that the elephants would be harmed in the process. The Rajasthan tourism group, which hosts the festival every year failed to sign up the elephants with the Animal Welfare Board, and provide appropriate documents. As a result of this, the organizers decided to rename it as the “Holi Festival.” The Tourism Department’s decision to cancel comes in the wake of protests by [People for Ethical Treatment of Animals|People for Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA)].

Srinivasan|first=Amrutur|title=Hinduism For Dummies|date=8 July 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0470878583|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=GnvXy2RlqrcC&pg=PA249 249]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jaipur.org.uk/fairs-festivals/elephant-festival.html | title=Elephant Festival | publisher=jaipur.org.uk | accessdate=August 27, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Elephant Festival|url=http://www.jaipur.org.uk/fairs-festivals/elephant-festival.html|accessdate=29 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Elephant Festival 2014|url=http://www.mapsofindia.com/rajasthan/elephant-festival.html|accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Elephant Festival of Jaipur|url=http://www.tourismtravelindia.com/rajasthanportal/fairandfestival/ElephantFestival.html|accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.incrediblerealindia.com/travel-tips-fairs-festivals-in-india-elephant-festival.shtml|title=Fairs & Festivals in India - Elephant Festival|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|accessdate=29 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Elephant Festival Cancelled|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jaipur/Elephant-festival-cancelled/articleshow/32039002.cms|accessdate=29 March 2014|newspaper=Times of India|date=March 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Rajasthan Cancels Elephant Festival|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-newdelhi/rajasthan-cancels-elephant-festival/article4552933.ece|accessdate=29 March 2014|newspaper=The Hindu|date=March 27, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Freger: Painted Elephants|url=http://sgustok.org/art/charles-freger-painted-elephants|newspaper=Sgustok Magazine|date=September 2, 2015}}</ref>

Majority Leader-Elect |before_election = |before_party = |after_election = |after_party = Socialist Group }} The '''1979 European elections''' were parliamentary elections held across all 9 (at the time) [[European Community]] [[European Union member state|member states]]. They were the first [[Elections in the European Union|European elections]] to be held, allowing citizens to elect 410 [[Member of the European Parliament|MEPs]] to the [[European Parliament]], and also the first international election in history.
Seats in the Parliament had been allocated to the states according to population, and in some cases were divided into [[European Parliament constituency|constituencies]], but members sat according to political groups.
==Background== The [[Treaty of Rome]] which established the Communities specified that the [[European Parliament]] must be elected by [[universal suffrage]] using a common [[voting system]]. The [[Council of the European Union]] was responsible for setting up the elections but it had procrastinated. As a stop-gap measure, members were appointed to the Parliament by the member states from their own national parliaments, as they had done since the Common Assembly.<ref name="Hoskyns">{{cite book| last = Hoskyns | first = Catherine |author2=Michael Newman | title = Democratizing the European Union: Issues for the twenty-first Century (Perspectives on Democratization | publisher = [[Manchester University Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-7190-5666-6 }}</ref> The Parliament was unhappy with this and threatened to take the Council to the [[European Court of Justice]]. The Council eventually agreed to elections and the first European Parliament elections were held in 1979 after proposals were put forward in the mid 1970s.<ref name="Hoskyns"/><ref name="PatijnReport">[http://aei.pitt.edu/1922/01/EP_election_decision.pdf Patijn Report]</ref> The issue of a common voting method was left undecided, and even to this day the voting methods vary from member state to member state, although all have used some form of proportional representation since 1999.
==Campaigns== [[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F056098-0019, Nürnberg, SPD Europa-Wahlkampf, Schmidt.jpg|thumb|left|[[Helmut Schmidt]] on the campaign trail in 1979]] The campaigns varied. The former [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democrat]] [[Chancellor of Germany (Federal Republic)|German Chancellor]] [[Willy Brandt]] took an international campaign to France, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands to boost the Socialist group. On the other hand, the former [[Prime Minister of France]] [[Jacques Chirac]] used the election to gauge his popularity against the then-[[President of France]] [[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing]], in anticipation of a presidential bid in 1981.<ref name="TIME">[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,946309,00.html Electing a New Parliament], [[Time Magazine]] 11 June 1979</ref>
==Election== {{Politics of the European Union mini}} In June, the 410 [[Member of the European Parliament|members]] were elected by universal suffrage. At the time there were no rules on the system of election to be used. The United Kingdom used a [[plurality voting system]] for multiple small constituencies in England, Wales and Scotland but the other member states used [[proportional representation]] for fewer larger constituencies (usually the member state itself as a single constituency), albeit with different methods of seat allocation.
The electorate took little interest<ref name="TIME"/> but average [[voter turnout]] was 63%. The lowest turn out was in the United Kingdom with 32.2%: all others were above 50% apart from Denmark. Aside from Belgium and Luxembourg, where [[Compulsory voting|voting is compulsory]], the highest turnout was in Italy with 84.9%.<ref>[http://www.cvce.eu/obj/rates_of_participation_in_european_elections_1979_2009-en-7dc3cc1c-13f3-43a6-865f-8f17cf307ef7.html Rates of participation in European elections (1979–2004)] on CVCE website</ref>
==Final results== Socialist parties working together under the Europe-wide [[Party of European Socialists|Confederation of Socialist Parties]] won the most seats: the resultant Socialist group had 113 MEPs. Christian Democrat parties united within the pan-European [[European People's Party]] came second, with the resultant group having 107 MEPs. The largest third force was the Conservative [[European Democrats]] with 64, followed by [[Party of the European Left|Communists]] with 44. The [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe|Liberal Democrats]] had 40 seats, although their candidate was elected as President.
The groups formed were loose coalitions based on the groups founded in previous years, but they soon became the basis for modern European political parties.
{| class="wikitable" !colspan=4|[[Apportionment in the European Parliament|National distribution of seats]] |- !State !Seats !State !Seats |- |{{FRA}} |81 |{{FRG}} |81 |- |{{ITA}} |81 |{{GBR}} |81 |- |{{NED}} |25 |{{BEL}} |24 |- |{{DEN}} |16 |{{IRL}} |15 |- |{{LUX}} |6 !colspan="2"|  |} {{EP79Results}}
==Post election== [[File:Simone Veil, gymnase Japy 2008 02 27 n5.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.7|[[Simone Veil]], elected as the first female President]] [[Louise Weiss]], who was 86 at the time, was found to be Parliament's oldest member and hence presided over the chamber while the election of the [[President of the European Parliament|President]] took place (July 1979). Before that could happen however, she immediately had to deal with [[Ian Paisley]] MEP who, in the first speech of the session, protested that the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|British flag]] outside the building was flying upside down.<ref>Matthew Tempest and agencies [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/jan/19/northernireland.devolution Paisley to stand down as MEP], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 19 January 2004</ref> She dealt with the interruption swiftly. The confrontation was seen as one of her finest hours and she later confided that, as a grandmother, she was used to dealing with "recalcitrant youngsters".<ref>[http://www.europeanvoice.com/article/imported/a-number-of-names-worth-remembering-…/37506.aspx A number of names worth remembering ...], ''[[European Voice]]'', 26 November 1998</ref>
There were five candidates for [[President of the European Parliament]]: [[Giorgio Amendola]], Italian [[Party of the European Left|Communist]]; [[Emma Bonino]], Italian [[European Free Alliance|Technical Independent]]; Christian de La Malène, French [[Union for Europe of the Nations|Progressive Democrat]]; [[Simone Veil]], French [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party|Liberal]], and Mario Zagari, Italian [[Party of European Socialists|Socialist]].<ref name="Veil election">[http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?language=EN&type=IM-PRESS&reference=20070109BKG01804 Election of the President of the European Parliament], [[Europa (web portal)|European Parliament]]</ref>
In the first ballot, Veil secured 183 of the 380 votes cast – eight short of the absolute majority needed. The next closest contender was Zagari with 118 votes, then Amendola with 44, de la Malène with 26 and Bonino with 9. Bonino and de la Malène dropped out and Veil secured an absolute majority in the second ballot with 192 of the 377 votes cast (Zagari gained 128 and Amendola 47). Veil was elected as the first President of the elected Parliament, and first female President of the Parliament since it was founded in 1952.<ref name="Veil election" />
The following were elected as Vice-Presidents: Danielle De March, [[Basil de Ferranti]], Bruno Friedrich, Guido Gonella, Gérard Jacquet, Hans Katzer, Poul Møller, [[Pierre Pflimlin]], [[Bríd Rodgers]], Marcel Albert Vandewiele, [[Anne Vondeling]] and [[Mario Zagari]].<ref name="Veil election"/>
Previously the Parliament was a weak consultative assembly, the members of which were part-time. With the elections the new body of [[Member of the European Parliament|MEPs]] were full-time, energetic and more diverse. As soon as the Parliament was established the "old guard" MEPs of the larger parties sought to raise the bar at which a [[European Parliament political group]] could be formed (the status gave financial support and representation in committees). This move was quickly blocked by smaller groups working together and [[filibuster]]ing the proposal. The ties formed at this time laid the foundations of the [[Rainbow Group (1984–89)|Rainbow]] group: an alliance of left-wing and [[Green party|green]] parties<ref name="Hoskyns"/> which later became the [[European Greens–European Free Alliance]] group.

[[Image:globalnightcommute.jpg|thumb|Global Night Commute in [[Portland, Oregon]]]] [[File:GNC, Boston.JPG|thumb|[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] displays its Global Message]]
'''Global Night Commute''' was a worldwide event organized by the makers of the film ''[[Invisible Children]]'' through the organization [[Invisible Children, Inc.]] It took place on April 29, 2006. Youths from around the world walked to city centers and spent the night in parks to show support for [[Ugandan]] children who walk every night into city centers attempting to avoid capture by the [[Lord's Resistance Army]] (LRA).
== Overview == These children, between the ages of 3 and 17, from [[Acholiland]] in Northern Uganda, are referred to as "night commuters". They walk up to 20 km (12 mi) from [[internally displaced person]] camps to larger towns, notably [[Gulu]], in search of safety from the LRA.
The Global Night Commute was similar to other initiatives raising awareness about the plight of the children in Acholiland like the [[Gulu Walk]] that took place in over 40 cities internationally in October 2005; however, the Global Night Commute took place on a much larger scale. Over 58,000 people signed up to participate in the event, but over 80,000 attended in total; it took place in 130 cities in seven countries.<ref name=gnc>{{cite web|title=Global Night Commute |url=http://www.invisiblechildren.com/theMovement/globalNightCommute/ |accessdate=2006-04-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060425060858/http://www.invisiblechildren.com/theMovement/globalNightCommute/ |archivedate=2006-04-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The goal of the event was to raise awareness and ultimately end Africa's longest running conflict by facilitating a change in the policies of the United States government. The slogan for the event is "On April 29th, we gathered. To make a difference. To end a war."

The '''Interactive Fiction Competition''' (also known as IFComp) is one of several annual competitions for works of [[interactive fiction]]. It has been held since 1995. It is intended for fairly short games, as judges are only allowed to spend two hours playing a game before deciding how many points to award it. The competition has been described as the "[[Super Bowl]]" of interactive fiction.<ref name="wsj-20051115"/>
== Organization == The competition is organized by ''Stephen Granade''.<ref name="wiredfilm-20060817"/> Although the first competition had separate sections for [[Inform]] and [[TADS]] games, subsequent competitions have not been divided into sections and are open to games produced by any method, provided that the software used to play the game is freely available. Anyone can judge the games, and anyone can donate a prize. Almost always, there are enough prizes donated that anyone who enters will get one. Entries are required to be released as [[freeware]] or [[public domain]], reflecting the general non-profit ethos of the IF community.{{cn|date=June 2018}}
In addition to the main competition, the entries take part in the Miss Congeniality contest, where the participating authors vote for three games (not including their own). This was started in 1998 to distribute that year's surplus prizes; this additional contest has remained unchanged since then, even without the original reason for its existence.
In 2016, operation of the competition was taken over by the [https://iftechfoundation.org/ Interactive Fiction Technology Foundation].<ref name="gamasutra-20160630"/><ref name="rockpapershotgun-20161207"/><ref name="rockpapershotgun-20170703"/>
The competition differs from the [[XYZZY Awards]], as authors must specifically submit games to the Interactive Fiction Competition, but all games released in the past year are eligible for the XYZZY Awards. Many games win awards in both competitions.
== Winners == The following is a list of first place winners to date: *'''2017:''' ''The Wizard Sniffer'' by Buster Hudson *'''2016:''' ''Detectiveland'' by [[Robin Johnson]] *'''2015:''' ''Brain Guzzlers from Beyond!'' by Steph Cherrywell *'''2014:''' ''Hunger Daemon'' by Sean M. Shore *'''2013:''' ''Coloratura'' by Lynnea Glasser *'''2012:''' ''Andromeda Apocalypse'' by Marco Innocenti *'''2011:''' ''Taco Fiction'' by Ryan Veeder *'''2010:''' ''Aotearoa'' by Matt Wigdahl *'''2009:''' ''Rover's Day Out'' by Jack Welch and Ben Collins-Sussman *'''2008:''' ''[[Violet (video game)|Violet]]'' by Jeremy Freese *'''2007:''' ''[[Lost Pig]]'' by Admiral Jota (writing as Grunk) *'''2006:''' ''[[Floatpoint]]'' by [[Emily Short]] *'''2005:''' ''[[Vespers (video game)|Vespers]]'' by Jason Devlin *'''2004:''' ''[[Luminous Horizon]]'' by Paul O'Brian *'''2003:''' ''[[Slouching Towards Bedlam]]'' by Star Foster and Daniel Ravipinto *'''2002:''' ''[[Another Earth, Another Sky]]'' by Paul O'Brian *'''2001:''' ''[[All Roads]]'' by [[Jon Ingold]] *'''2000:''' ''[[Kaged]]'' by Ian Finley *'''1999:''' ''[[Winter Wonderland (game)|Winter Wonderland]]'' by Laura A. Knauth *'''1998:''' ''[[Photopia]]'' by [[Adam Cadre]] *'''1997:''' ''[[The Edifice]]'' by Lucian P. Smith *'''1996:''' ''[[The Meteor, the Stone and a Long Glass of Sherbet]]'' by [[Graham Nelson]] *'''1995''': Tie: ''[[A Change in the Weather]]'' by [[Andrew Plotkin]], ''[[Uncle Zebulon's Will]]'' by [[Magnus Olsson (programmer)|Magnus Olsson]]
== Reception == A reviewer for ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' said of the 2008 competition, "Once again, the IF Competition delivers some of the best writing in games."<ref name="avclub-20081222"/> The 2008 competition was described as containing "some real standouts both in quality of puzzles and a willingness to stretch the definition of text adventures/interactive fiction."<ref name="kotaku-20081117"/>

{{Music of Azerbaijan}} {{Infobox settlement |name = International World of Mugham Festival |settlement_type= |native_name = |image_skyline = Mugam 034.jpg |imagesize = 200px |coordinates = |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = {{flag|Azerbaijan}} |subdivision_name1 = |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date =2009 |website = }} The '''International World of Mugham Festival''' ({{lang-az|Beynəlxalq Muğam Dünyası Festivalı}}) is an annual music festival of [[Music of Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani]] [[mugham]] music.
The first festival was held on [[Heydar Aliyev Foundation]]’s initiative, on March 18–25, 2009, in [[Baku]]. Official opening ceremony of the festival was held on March 20, in [[International Mugham Center of Azerbaijan]]. International scientific symposium, international contest of mugham singers, multiple mugham operas, symphonic and classical mugham concerts were held during the festival. The festival was concluded by gala concert, which was held on March 25, 2009 in [[Heydar Aliyev Palace]], in Baku.<ref>{{Cite news| title=Насыщенный год| url=http://www.zerkalo.az/2009-12-31/culture/5873-filarmoniya-muradadigezalzade| publisher=| date=| accessdate=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408222650/http://www.zerkalo.az/2009-12-31/culture/5873-filarmoniya-muradadigezalzade| archivedate=2014-04-08| df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Mugam feast in prospect | url=http://news.az/articles/culture/32515 | publisher=news.az | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
==International scientific symposium of mugham== International scientific symposium of mugham was held during the international festival and lasted for 3 days. Meetings of the symposium had been held in three sections, in the end of which was published a special book.<ref>{{Cite news | title = В рамках фестиваля "Мир мугама" обсуждены научные проблемы | url=http://1news.az/culture/20110318063830279.html | publisher=1news.az | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
About 30 scientists, musicians, and also promoters of traditional eastern music from the [[United States|USA]], [[Great Britain]], [[Russia]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Germany]], [[Turkey]], [[Netherlands]], [[Hungary]], [[China]], [[Tunisia]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Iraq]], [[Iran]], [[Morocco]], [[Tajikistan]] and other countries took part at the symposium.<ref>{{Cite news | title = FESTIVAL INTERNATIONAL DU MUGHAM à BAKOU, AZERBAÏDJAN | url=http://semioweb.msh-paris.fr/corpus/azeributa/Pages_html/Festival_International_du_Mugham_Bakou_2009.htm | publisher= | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
Participants of the symposium were such ethnomusicologist scientists, as Steven Blum (Professor of [[New York City|New York]] municipal university, expert of [[UNESCO]]), Dieter Christensen (Professor of [[Columbia University]] in New York), Wim van Zanten (vice president of International Council of Traditional Music under UNESCO), Professor Jean During from France, Jurgen Elsner (Professor of [[Humboldt University of Berlin]]), [[Hiromi Lorraine Sakata]] (Professor of the [[University of California]]), Inna Naroditskaya (Northwestern University, Chicago <ref>{{cite book|last=Naroditskaya|first=Inna|title=The Song from the Land of Fire: Azerbaijani Mugham in the Soviet and Post-Soviet Periods|year=2003|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415940214}}</ref>), Luis Duran and James Parkin (hosts of most popular “World Routes” program on [[BBC Radio]]), Bernard Kleikamp - chairman and the owner of “Pan Records” company, Professor Rovshan Yunusov from Uzbekistan, Professor of [[Moscow Conservatory]] Violetta Yunusova, Abduvali Abdurashidov-chairman of “Makoma Academy” in [[Dushanbe]] and others.
Presentations about musical cultures of Azerbaijan, Iran, Turkey, Pakistan, India, Tunisia, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan were sounded in the sections of the festival and the issue of Nagorno-Karabakh War was also raised there.<ref>{{Cite news| title="Muğam dünyası" II Beynəlxalq muğam festivalı| url=http://contact.az/topics_ru.asp?id=3020&pb=19&vr=az&yr=2011&mn=3&day=15&pg=26&cl=3&cmpg=1&cmcl=1&sbpg=1&sbcl=1&srch=0&ms=NaN&clnd=0&mdn=1| publisher=| date=| accessdate=}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| title=Second International Festival "World of Mugam"| url=http://contact.az/topics_ru.asp?id=3029&pb=19&vr=en&yr=2011&mn=3&day=15&pg=88&cl=9&cmpg=1&cmcl=1&sbpg=1&sbcl=1&srch=0&ms=NaN&clnd=0&mdn=1| publisher=| date=| accessdate=}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Program of the symposium== * March 17 – Press conference of International World of Mugham Festival. * March 18 – Opening ceremony of International Scientific Symposium in [[Azerbaijan State Museum of History]]. * March 19 – Conferences of sections of the International Scientific Symposium in Azerbaijan State Museum of History. * March 20 – Conferences of the International Symposium in Azerbaijan State Museum of History. * March 20 – Closing conference of a circular table in Azerbaijan State Museum of History. * March 20 – Ceremonies of celebrating “[[Nowruz|Novruz Bayram]]” in [[Old City (Baku)|Icheri Sheher]]. * March 20 – Official receipt in honor of participants of the festival. * March 22 – Meeting with friends of Azerbaijani mugham in Composers’ Union of Azerbaijan.

'''''Les Fabuleux Exploits d'Eddy Merckx''''' (''The Fabulous Exploits of Eddy Merckx'') is a 1973 [[celebrity comics|celebrity comic]] drawn by [[Christian Lippens]]<ref>https://www.lambiek.net/artists/l/lippens_christian.htm</ref> and written by [[Yves Duval]],<ref>https://www.lambiek.net/artists/d/duval_yves.htm</ref> based on the popularity of Belgian cycling champion [[Eddy Merckx]]. It tells the story of his career and is drawn in a realistic style. The book was created for Arts & Voyages Gamma.<ref>https://www.bedetheque.com/serie-8871-BD-Fabuleux-exploits-d-Eddy-Merckx.html</ref><ref>http://www.bande-dessinee.org/bd/bd02.nsf/e7e8940dea556cc1c125649100459ac0/2636ec8f76eb34a7c1257af9005ca759!OpenDocument</ref>
==Plot==
The book starts off with Merckx winning his first amateur championship in [[Sallanches]] in 1964 and follows all his conquests, ending with him breaking the world record in cycling (1972) in Mexico.<ref>http://www.dhnet.be/sports/football/nos-grands-sportifs-en-bd-51b7c6b3e4b0de6db98d72d5</ref>

{{see also|Stop Trump movement}} {{pp-pc1|expiry=01:46, 1 February 2019|small=yes}} {{Use American English|date=July 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Donald Trump series}}
This is a list of <!-- "notable" persons only, as defined by the Wikipedia Manual of Style. --> '''Anti-Trump''' or '''Never Trump Republicans''' and [[Conservatism in the United States|conservatives]] who announced their opposition to the election of [[Donald Trump]], the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 Republican Party nominee]] and eventual winner of the election, as the [[President of the United States]]. It also includes former Republicans who left the party due to their opposition to Trump and as well as Republicans who endorsed a different candidate. It does not include Republicans who opposed Trump during the [[primary election]] campaign but never announced opposition to Trump as the nominee. Some of the Republicans on this list threw their support to Trump after he won the presidential election, while many of them continue to oppose Trump.
Research on the Never Trump movement shows that [[Mormon]] and female Republicans were the most likely groups to oppose Trump's candidacy while non-Mormon and male Republicans were the most supportive.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Johnson |first=Lauren R. |last2=McCray |first2=Deon |last3=Ragusa |first3=Jordan M. |date=January 11, 2018 |title=#NeverTrump: Why Republican members of Congress refused to support their party’s nominee in the 2016 presidential election |url=https://doi.org/10.1177/2053168017749383 |journal=Research & Politics |language=en |volume=5 |issue=1 |doi=10.1177/2053168017749383}}</ref> In the same study, establishment Republicans were found to be more likely to support Trump's candidacy, the opposite of what most observers, including Donald Trump himself, claimed.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://time.com/4526492/donald-trump-paul-ryan-shackles/ |title=Trump Says He's Taking 'Shackles Off' His Campaign |website=Time|access-date=January 12, 2018}}</ref>

===Former 2016 Republican presidential primary candidates=== All candidates signed a pledge to eventually support the party nominee. The following refused to honor it after Trump became the Republican presidential nominee.

[[United States Senate election in California, 2010|2010]] nominee for U.S. Senator from [[California]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ijr.com/2016/09/692812-after-more-than-a-year-of-bashing-trump-carly-fiorina-is-finally-aboard-the-trump-train |title=After More Than a Year of Bashing Trump, Carly Fiorina Is Finally Aboard the Trump Train |date=September 13, 2016 |website=[[Independent Journal Review]] |access-date=May 7, 2017}}</ref> (originally endorsed Trump for the general election but called for [[Mike Pence]] to take his place as nominee after the [[Access Hollywood tape recordings|Access Hollywood Tape]] surfaced)<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://twitter.com/CarlyFiorina/status/784781805148786691 |title=Carly Fiorina on Twitter |work=Twitter|access-date=May 7, 2017 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://time.com/4523922/carly-fiorina-donald-trump-mike-pence/ |title=Carly Fiorina: Donald Trump Should 'Step Aside' as Presidential Nominee |website=Time|access-date=May 7, 2017}}</ref> * [[Lindsey Graham]], [[List of United States Senators from South Carolina|United States Senator from South Carolina]] (2003–present) (voted for [[Evan McMullin]])<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/06/politics/lindsey-graham-donald-trump-hillary-clinton-not-vote/ |title=Lindsey Graham won't vote for Trump or Clinton in 2016 |first=Dana |last=Bash |date=May 6, 2016 |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=August 13, 2016}}</ref> * [[John Kasich]], [[Governor of Ohio]] (2011–present); {{Infobox film festival | name = Lone Pine Film Festival | logo = Lone Pine Film Festival Logo 2014.png | logo_alt = | logo_size = | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[Lone Pine, California]] | telephone = | founded = 1990 | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = | number = | date = | language = English | website = {{url|www.lonepinefilmfestival.org}} | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
The '''Lone Pine Film Festival''' is an annual film festival held in [[Lone Pine, California]], which celebrates the hundreds of films and television episodes that used Lone Pine, the [[Alabama Hills]], and the nearby [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] mountain range as film locations. Since the early years of filmmaking, directors and their production units have used the Lone Pine area to represent the iconic [[Western United States|American West]]. Since ''The Roundup'' (1920), the first documented film produced in the area, Lone Pine has played host to hundreds of the industry's best known directors and actors, among them directors [[William Wyler]], [[John Ford]], [[George Stevens]], and [[William Wellman]], and actors [[John Wayne]], [[Gene Autry]], [[Roy Rogers]], [[Bing Crosby]], and [[Barbara Stanwyck]]. The festival at Lone Pine was held for the first time in 1990, then called the Sierra Film Festival. In 2014, the festival celebrates its twenty-fifth silver anniversary.<ref name="lpff-25">{{cite web|title=Lone Pine Film Festival Celebrates 25 Years |publisher=Lone Pine Flm Festival |date=August 4, 2014 |url=http://www.lonepinefilmfestival.org/index.php/component/content/article/429 |accessdate=August 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812210451/http://www.lonepinefilmfestival.org/index.php/component/content/article/429 |archivedate=August 12, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Held annually over the [[Columbus Day]] weekend, the Lone Pine Film Festival is one of the most important Western film festivals in the United States.<ref name="american-cowboy">{{cite web|last=Herrera |first=Nathalie |title=The List: Western film festivals |publisher=American Cowboy |date= |url=http://www.americancowboy.com/travel/rodeo/list-western-film-festivals |accessdate=August 10, 2014}}</ref>
==History== The Lone Pine area was first used as a film location in 1920, when a movie production company came to the [[Alabama Hills]] to make the silent film ''[[The Round-Up (1920 film)|The Round-Up]]''.<ref name="lpcc-film">{{cite web|title=The Film Industry in the Lone Pine Area |publisher=Lone Pine Chamber of Commerce |url=http://lonepinechamber.org/history/the-film-industry-in-the-lone-pine-area/ |accessdate=August 10, 2014}}</ref> Other companies soon discovered the scenic location, and in the coming decades, over 400 films, 100 television episodes, and countless commercials used Lone Pine and the Alabama Hills as a film location.<ref name="lpcc-film"/> Some of the notable films shot here in the 1920s and 1930s include ''[[Riders of the Purple Sage (1925 film)|Riders of the Purple Sage]]'' (1925) with [[Tom Mix]], ''The Enchanted Hill'' (1926) with [[Jack Holt (actor)|Jack Holt]], ''Somewhere in Sonora'' (1927) with [[Ken Maynard]], ''[[Blue Steel (1934 film)|Blue Steel]]'' (1934) with [[John Wayne]], ''[[Hop-Along Cassidy]]'' (1935) with [[William Boyd (actor)|William Boyd]], ''[[The Charge of the Light Brigade (1936 film)|The Charge of the Light Brigade]]'' (1936) with Errol Flynn, ''[[Oh, Susanna! (1936 film)|Oh, Susanna!]]'' (1936) with [[Gene Autry]], ''[[Rhythm on the Range]]'' (1936) with [[Bing Crosby]], ''[[The Cowboy and the Lady (1938 film)|The Cowboy and the Lady]]'' (1938) with [[Gary Cooper]], ''[[Under Western Stars]]'' (1938) with [[Roy Rogers]], and ''[[Gunga Din (film)|Gunga Din]]'' (1939) with [[Cary Grant]].
In the coming decades, Lone Pine and the Alabama Hills continued to be used as the setting for Western films, including ''[[West of the Pecos (1945 film)|West of the Pecos]]'' (1945) with [[Robert Mitchum]], ''[[Thunder Mountain (1947 film)|Thunder Mountain]]'' (1947) with [[Tim Holt]], ''[[The Gunfighter]]'' (1950) with [[Gregory Peck]], ''[[The Nevadan]]'' (1950) with [[Randolph Scott]], ''[[Bad Day at Black Rock]]'' (1955) with [[Spencer Tracy]], ''[[Hell Bent for Leather (film)|Hell Bent for Leather]]'' (1960) with [[Audie Murphy]], ''[[How the West Was Won (film)|How the West Was Won]]'' (1962) with [[James Stewart]], ''[[Nevada Smith]]'' (1966) with [[Steve McQueen]], ''[[Joe Kidd]]'' (1972) with [[Clint Eastwood]], ''[[Maverick (film)|Maverick]]'' (1994) with [[Mel Gibson]], and ''[[The Lone Ranger (2013 film)|The Lone Ranger]]'' (2013) with [[Johnny Depp]]. Through the years, non-Western films also used the unique landscape of the area, including [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s ''[[Saboteur (film)|Saboteur]]'' (1942) with [[Robert Cummings]], ''[[Samson and Delilah (1949 film)|Samson and Delilah]]'' (1949) with [[Hedy Lamarr]], ''[[Star Trek V: The Final Frontier]]'' (1989) with [[William Shatner]], ''[[Tremors (film)|Tremors]]'' (1990) with [[Kevin Bacon]], ''[[The Postman (film)|The Postman]]'' (1997) with [[Kevin Costner]], and ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'' (2000) with [[Russell Crowe]].
In 1989, Lone Pine business and community leaders developed a plan to celebrate the film industry's heritage of using Lone Pine and the surrounding area as film locations to represent the iconic [[Western United States|American West]].<ref name="lpff-25"/> They invited numerous actors, directors, and producers who made films in the area throughout the years. The first film festival in Lone Pine was held on October 6 and 7 and was called the Sierra Film Festival.<ref name="lpff-25"/> Co-sponsored by a number of individuals and businesses, that first festival included numerous Western film celebrities, including [[Roy Rogers]], [[Richard Farnsworth]], [[Rand Brooks]], [[Pierce Lyden]], Loren Janes, [[William Witney]], and former stuntman Joe Yrigoyen.<ref name="lpff-25"/> The festival acknowledging its "deep appreciation and great gratitude" to Roy Rogers, who made his first film in Lone Pine in 1938 with ''[[Under Western Stars]]''. Rogers dedicated an historical stone marker placed at Whitney Portal and Movie Road during the festival.<ref name="lpff-25"/> The bronze plaque on the stone reads: "Sierra Film Festival, 70 years of Movie History, October 6 & 7, 1990, Movie Flats – Lone Pine".<ref name="lpff-25"/>
==Events== The Lone Pine Film Festival takes place annually over the Columbus Day weekend, the second weekend of October. The festival opens at the Lone Pine Film History Museum on Thursday night for a gala reception. Over the next three days, a variety of events take place, including: * Guided tours into the Alabama Hills to notable film locations (by bus or car caravan) * Film screenings * Guest speakers and panels * Sunrise photo tours and cowboy poetry * Wild West shows * Rodeo shows * Sunday afternoon parade of celebrities * Sunday night closing campfire<ref name="lpff-events">{{cite web|title=Events |publisher=Lone Pine Film Festival |url=http://www.lonepinefilmfestival.org/index.php/events |accessdate=August 11, 2014}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Jeanne Clery | image = File:JeanneClery.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1966|11|23}} | birth_place = [[Pennsylvania]] United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1986|4|5|1966|11|26}} | death_place = [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania]] | occupation = | parents = Connie and Howard Clery }} The murder of '''Jeanne Clery''' occurred in 1986, in [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania]] at [[Lehigh University]]. Clery, who was a student at the time of her death, was killed in her campus [[dormitory]]. Clery's parents, who believed the University had failed to share vital information with its students regarding campus safety, campaigned for legislative reform for several years following their daughter's death. Their sustained efforts ultimately resulted in the passage of the [[Clery Act]], a federal law requiring all universities and colleges receiving federal [[Student financial aid (United States)|student financial aid]] programs to report crime statistics, alert campus of imminent dangers, and distribute an Annual Campus Security Report to current and prospective students and employees.
Since the act's passage in 1990, numerous institutions have been found noncompliant and significantly fined. From 2008–2012, 14 higher education institutions were fined for Clery Act noncompliance.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://educationlaw.ncbar.org/newsletters/educationlawnov2013/clery | title=The Clery Act: Costs of Noncompliance | accessdate=July 15, 2017 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531124809/http://educationlaw.ncbar.org/newsletters/educationlawnov2013/clery | archivedate=2014-05-31}}</ref> Large scale Clery violations resulted in financial fines at institutions such as [[Pennsylvania State University]], [[Eastern Michigan University]] and [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University]].
==Incident== On April 5, 1986, Jeanne Clery was raped and murdered in Stoughton Hall at Lehigh University by Josoph M. Henry, who was also a student. Clery was awoken by Henry in the process of robbing her, and Henry then beat, cut, raped, sodomized, and strangled Jeanne.<ref name="LA Times 1989 Article Detailing Clery's Death">{{cite news|last1=BEYETTE|first1=BEVERLY|title=Campus Crime Crusade : Howard and Connie Clery Lost Their Daughter to a Crazed Thief; NoThey're Angry and Fighting Back|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-08-10/news/vw-301_1_campus-crime-statistics|accessdate=22 February 2015|publisher=LA Times|date=August 10, 1989}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gross |first=Ken |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20116872,00.html |title=After Their Daughter Is Murdered at College, Her Grieving Parents Mount a Crusade for Campus Safety |publisher=People.com |date=February 19, 1990 |accessdate=2011-10-30}}</ref> Prior to Jeanne's death, there were reports that her dorm had had 181 situations of auto-locking doors being propped open by residents. The propped doors, as well as Clery's own room door left unlocked (for her roommate, who forgot her key) are believed to be how Henry entered Stoughton Hall.{{Citation needed|date=June 2015}} He was reported to the police after confessing the murder to his friends and was subsequently apprehended.<ref name="pasupct1997">{{cite web | title=Com. v. Henry, 550 Pa. 346 (1997) | publisher=Justia | url=http://law.justia.com/cases/pennsylvania/supreme-court/1997/550-pa-346-1.html | accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref> He was later sentenced to death via the electric chair, a decision upheld by the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania upon appeal.<ref name="pasupct1997"/><ref>{{cite web | title=Ex-Lehigh Student Sentenced To Electric Chair for Murder | publisher=The New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/us/ex-lehigh-student-sentenced-to-electric-chair-for-murder.html | accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref> In 2002, after his death sentence was thrown out, Henry opted to give up his appeal rights and accepted life in prison rather than face another death penalty hearing with the possibility of a reinstated death sentence.<ref>{{cite web | title=Henry trades appeal rights for life in prison for 1986 rape, murder of Lehigh student | publisher=The Morning Call | url=http://articles.mcall.com/2002-08-31/news/3417898_1_death-sentence-death-penalty-appeal-rights | accessdate=2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Insufficient public warnings regarding criminal activity on campus=== As Connie and Howard Clery learned more about their daughter's death, they grew convinced that their daughter had died because of "slipshod" security on campus. Beyond this, they believed the university had "a rapidly escalating crime rate, which they didn't tell anybody about". At the time, Lehigh University's vice president John Smeaton, denied claims saying security measures were "more than adequate, reasonable and appropriate for our setting and our situation. You can't prevent everything from happening."<ref name="LA Times 1989 Article Detailing Clery's Death"/> Nonetheless, the Clery family believed that campus crime statistics had been significantly underreported, and led to Clery's parents founding the nonprofit organization Security On Campus, Inc. Today the foundation is called the Clery Center for Security On Campus.<ref name="Clery Center for Campus Security">{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://clerycenter.org/our-history|website=Clery Center for Campus Security|publisher=Clery Center for Campus Security|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.securityoncampus.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=271&Itemid=60 |title=Complying With The Jeanne Clery Act |publisher=Securityoncampus.org |date= |accessdate=2011-10-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rd.com/family/ranking-the-safest-and-worst-college-campuses/ | title=Ranking the Safest (and Least Secure) College Campuses|work=Readers Digest |year=2008 |accessdate=2012-04-06}}</ref>
==Clery Act== {{Main article|Clery Act}}
===Enactment=== The Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act or 'Clery Act' is a federal [[statute]] codified at {{uscsub|20|1092|f}}, implementing regulations in the [[United States|U.S.]] [[Code of Federal Regulations]] at {{USCFR|34|668|46}}. The Clery Act, signed in 1990, was originally known as the Crime Awareness and Campus Security Act.
===Requirements=== The Clery Act requires all colleges and universities that participate in federal [[Student financial aid (United States)|financial aid]] programs to keep and disclose information about crime on and near their respective campuses. Compliance is monitored by the [[United States Department of Education]], which can impose [[civil penalties]], up to $56,906 per violation, against institutions for each infraction and can suspend institutions from participating in federal student financial aid programs.
Each year, institutions must publish and distribute their Annual Campus Security Report to current and prospective students and employees. This report is required to provide crime statistics for the prior three years, policy statements regarding various safety and security measures, campus crime prevention program descriptions, and procedures to be followed in the investigation and prosecution of alleged sex offenses.
Beyond this, universities are required to provide a Crime log, timely warnings to students, and crime statistics. The institution's police department or security departments are required to maintain a public log of all crimes reported to them, or those of which they are made aware. The Clery Act requires institutions to give timely warnings of crimes that represent a threat to the safety of students or employees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://clerycenter.org/clery-act-compliance|title=Clery Act Compliance|publisher=Clery Center for Security On Campus|accessdate=2013-09-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927061819/http://clerycenter.org/clery-act-compliance|archivedate=2013-09-27|df=}}</ref> Institutions are required to report on crimes such as: [[Murder]], [[Rape]], [[dating violence]], [[Robbery]], [[Arrest]], [[Hate crimes]] and disciplinary actions by the institution.
===Violations=== Since its founding, major incidents where universities were found in violation of the Clery act include Eastern Michigan University and the [[Murder of Laura Dickinson]], the [[Penn State sex abuse scandal]], and [[Virginia Tech shooting]] which received major media coverage.

{{unreliable sources|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = Pinocchio | image = File:Flip Wilson Sandy Duncan Liz Torres Pinocchio 1976.jpg | caption = (L-R) [[Flip Wilson]] as Fox, [[Sandy Duncan]] as Pinocchio, [[Liz Torres]] as Cat | director = [[Ron Field]], Sid Smith | producer = Bernard Rothman, Jack Wohl | writer = Based on novel by
[[Carlo Collodi]] | starring = [[Sandy Duncan]]
[[Danny Kaye]] | music = [[Billy Barnes (composer)|Billy Barnes]] | cinematography = | editing = Jerry Greene | studio = Vidtronics | distributor = [[CBS]] (original telecast)
VCI Entertainment (DVD) | released = March 27, 1976 (TV)
Oct 24, 2000 (DVD) | runtime = 73 mins. | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''Pinocchio''' is a 1976 made-for-TV musical starring [[Sandy Duncan]] in the title role and [[Danny Kaye]] as Gepetto. It was first broadcast March 27, 1976[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0207653/releaseinfo?ref_=tt_ov_inf ''Pinocchio'' (1976 TV musical) at IMDb - release dates] on [[CBS]][https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0207653/companycredits?ref_=tt_dt_co ''Pinocchio'' (1976 TV musical) Company Credits at IMDb] and rerun on April 18, 1977.[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/archive/8/85/20111007030341%21Flip_Wilson_Sandy_Duncan_Liz_Torres_Pinocchio_1977.JPG "Pinocchio"] - CBS press release for rerun of 18 Apr 1977 ==Plot summary== Framed by the story of a young theater girl's desire to study and work apart from her father, the classic children's story of ''[[Pinocchio]]'' is presented as a subplay with the young girl (Sandy Duncan) as Pinocchio and her father (Danny Kaye) as Geppetto. ==Cast== * [[Sandy Duncan]] ... [[Pinocchio]] * [[Danny Kaye]] ... [[Mister Geppetto|Gepetto]] * [[Clive Revill]] ... [[The Coachman|Coachman]] (alphabetically) * [[Don Correia]] ... Candlewick's Mate * Ben Lokey ... Dancer * [[Gary Morgan (actor)|Gary Morgan]] ... [[Candlewick (character)|Candlewick]] * Roy Smith ... Candlewick's Mate * [[Liz Torres]] ... [[The Fox and the Cat|Cat]] * [[Flip Wilson]] ... [[The Fox and the Cat|Fox]] ==Musical numbers== # "Talking to Myself" - Gepetto # "What's That?" - Pinocchio, Gepetto and ensemble # "I Like It" - Pinocchio and ensemble[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d8_4fTqDEg0 "I Like It"] sung by Sandy Duncan, YouTube # "The Money Tree" - Fox and Cat # "M-O-R-E" - Fox, Cat and Pinocchio # "Look at Me Now" - Gepetto and ensemble # "If I Could Start All Over, Would I?" - Pinocchio[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fb1gOdDUt-g "If I Could Start All Over, Would I?"] sung by Sandy Duncan, YouTube # "Fun, Fun, Fun" - Pinocchio and ensemble[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VrFtLu0eUEA&t=111s "Fun, Fun, Fun"] sung by Sandy Duncan and ensemble, YouTube # "I Want to Go Home" - Pinocchio and Gepetto ==Reception== ''Pinocchio'' won two [[Emmy Awards]] for Outstanding Individual Achievement in Children's Programming, one for Costume Design ([[Bill Hargate]]) and another for Videotape Editing. It was also nominated for Emmys for Outstanding Children's Special and Outstanding Makeup (designed by [[Stan Winston]]).[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0207653/awards?ref_=tt_awd ''Pinocchio'' (1976 TV musical) Awards at IMDb] ==Production notes== In 1976, this was the first of two TV musical adaptations of a children's classic starring [[Danny Kaye]] and costarring a female as a young boy. On December 12, 1976, [[NBC]] teleast ''[[Peter Pan (1976 musical)|Peter Pan]]'' with Kaye as Captain Hook and [[Mia Farrow]] in the title role. [[Ron Field]] was [[choreographer]]. ==Home media== "Pinocchio" was released on [[DVD]] on October 24, 2000.[https://www.amazon.com/Pinocchio-Sandy-Duncan/dp/B00004W5VF Pinocchio (1976 TV musical) at Amazon] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0207653|Pinocchio (1976 TV musical)}} {{Pinocchio}} [[Category:1970s adventure films]] [[Category:1970s fantasy films]] [[Category:1976 films]] [[Category:1976 in American television]] [[Category:1976 television specials]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:CBS television specials]] [[Category:Children's fantasy films]] [[Category:Musicals based on novels]] [[Category:Musical television films]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:Pinocchio films]] [[Category:Television programs based on fairy tales]] [[Category:Television articles with incorrect naming style]]

{{Infobox serial killer | name=Robert Lee Yates | image=Robert Lee Yates (criminal).png | image_size=175px | caption=Spokane Police Mugshot (2000) | birth_name=Robert Lee Yates Jr. | alias=Spokane Serial Killer | birth_date={{birth date and age|1952|05|27}} | birth_place=[[Spokane, Washington]], U.S. | victims=18+ | country=United States | states=[[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] | beginyear=1975 | endyear=1998 | apprehended=April 18, 2000 | penalty=1. 408 years in [[prison]],
[[Spokane County, Washington|Spokane County]]
2. [[Capital punishment|Death]] (commuted to life),
[[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]]
}} '''Robert Lee Yates Jr.''' (born May 27, 1952) is an American [[serial killer]] from [[Spokane, Washington]]. From 1996 to 1998, Yates is known to have murdered at least 13 women, all of whom were [[prostitutes]] working on E. Sprague Avenue, in Spokane. Yates also confessed to two murders committed in [[Walla Walla, Washington|Walla Walla]] in 1975 and a 1988 murder committed in [[Skagit County, Washington|Skagit County]]. In 2002, Yates was convicted of killing two women in [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]] and sentenced to death, but his death sentences were commuted to life without parole after Washington State outlawed the death penalty in 2018. He is currently serving life in prison at the [[Washington State Penitentiary]]. ==Early life== Yates grew up in [[Oak Harbor, Washington]]{{cite web |url=http://www.karisable.com/skazyates.htm |title=Serial Killer Robert Yates |last=Sable Burns |first=Kari |publisher=www.karisable.com |accessdate=May 14, 2009}} in a middle-class family that attended a local [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh-day Adventist]] church. He graduated from [[Oak Harbor High School (Washington)|Oak Harbor High School]] in 1970, and in 1975, he was hired by the Washington State Department of Corrections to work as a correction officer at the [[Washington State Penitentiary]] in Walla Walla. In October 1977 Yates enlisted in the [[United States Army]], in which he became certified to fly civilian transport airplanes and helicopters. Yates was stationed in various countries outside the continental United States, including [[Germany]] and later [[Somalia]] and Haiti during the United Nations peacekeeping missions of the 1990s. He earned several military awards and medals during his eighteen and a half year military career, including three [[Army Achievement Medal]]s, three [[Army Commendation Medal]]s, two [[Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal]]s, and three [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]]s. Yates left the Army in April 1996, apparently a year and a half short of being eligible for his full retirement benefits and pension. At this time the military was reducing its numbers so he got his full retirement despite being short of the customary 20 years served.{{cite web |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/yates/guy_8.html |title=Robert Lee Yates was the Spokane serial killer |publisher=[[Crime Library]] |page= 8 |accessdate=May 15, 2009}} ==Murders== The murders Yates committed between 1988 and 1998 in Spokane all involved prostitutes working along Spokane's E. Sprague Avenue. The victims were initially solicited for prostitution by Yates, who would have sex with them (often in his 1979 [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] van), sometimes do drugs with them, then kill them and dump their bodies in rural locations. All of his victims died of gunshot wounds to the head; eight of the murders were committed with a [[Raven Arms MP-25|Raven .25-caliber]] [[handgun]], and one [[attempted murder]] was linked to the same model of handgun.{{cite web |url=http://www.francesfarmersrevenge.com/stuff/serialkillers/yates.htm |title=Serial Killer Robert Lee Yates Jr |publisher=www.francesfarmersrevenge.com |accessdate=May 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422025822/http://www.francesfarmersrevenge.com/stuff/serialkillers/yates.htm |archivedate=April 22, 2009 |df= }} Autopsies of two of the victims indicated that the killer was a marksman aiming for the heart.[[Burl Barer|Barer, Burl]] (2012). ''[[Body Count (book)|Body Count]]'' New York: Kensington Books. One particularly bizarre detail of Yates' murders involved the case of Melody Murfin, whose body was buried just outside the bedroom window of Yates' family home.{{cite web |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/yates/up_11.html |title=Robert Lee Yates was the Spokane serial killer |publisher=[[Crime Library]] |page=11 |accessdate=May 15, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601204540/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/yates/up_11.html |archive-date=2009-06-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }} On August 1, 1998, Yates picked up prostitute Christine Smith, who managed to escape after being shot, assaulted and robbed.{{cite web |url=http://maamodt.asp.radford.edu/Psyc%20405/serial%20killers/Yates,%20Robert%20Lee.htm |title=Robert Lee Yates |accessdate=May 15, 2009}}{{rs?|date=May 2012}} On September 19, 1998, Yates was asked to give a [[DNA]] sample to Spokane police after being stopped; he refused, stating that it was too extreme of a request for a "family man". ==Convictions and appeals== Yates was arrested on April 18, 2000, for the murder of Jennifer Joseph. After his arrest a search warrant was executed on a 1977 white Corvette that he had previously owned. A white Corvette had been identified as the vehicle that one of the victims had last been seen in. Coincidentally, Yates had been pulled over in this vehicle while the Task Force was searching for it, but the field interview report was misread as saying "Camaro" not "Corvette", thus the incident was not realized until after Yates had been arrested. After searching the Corvette, police discovered blood that they linked to Jennifer Joseph and DNA from Yates that they then tied to 12 other victims.Fuhrman, Mark (2001). '' Murder in Spokane '' New York: Harper Collins. In 2000 he was charged with 13 counts of [[first-degree murder]] and one count of attempted first-degree murder in Spokane County Superior Court. As part of a plea bargain in which Yates confessed to the murders to avoid the [[death penalty]], he was sentenced to 408 years in prison.{{cite news |url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/sections/us/DailyNews/serialkillers010112.html |title=Wash. Prosecutors Seek Death Penalty for Serial Killer |publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=May 15, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20010421083705/http://www.abcnews.go.com/sections/us/DailyNews/serialkillers010112.html |archivedate = April 21, 2001}} In 2001 Yates was charged in [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]] with the murders of two additional women. The prosecution sought the [[death penalty]] for the deaths of Melinda L. Mercer in 1997 and Connie Ellis in 1998, which were thought to be linked to the killings in Spokane County. On September 19, 2002, Yates was convicted of those murders and subsequently [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]] by [[lethal injection]] on October 3, 2002.{{cite news |url=http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/texis.cgi/web/vortex/display?slug=webyates03&date=20021003&query=%22Robert+Lee+Yates%22 |title=Serial killer Yates sentenced to death| date=October 3, 2002 |work=[[Seattle Times]]|accessdate=September 25, 2012}} The 2002 death sentence was appealed on grounds that Yates believed his 2000 plea bargain to be "all-encompassing", and that a life sentence for 13 murders and a death sentence for two constituted "disproportionate, freakish, wanton and random" application of the death penalty. The arguments were rejected in 2007 by the [[Washington Supreme Court]].State high court upholds death penalty for Yates (September 28, 2007). [http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2003909396_yates28m.html Seattle ''Times'' archive]. Retrieved September 17, 2014. A September 19, 2008 execution date was [[stay of execution|stayed]] by Chief Justice [[Gerry L. Alexander]] pending additional appeals.{{cite web | url=http://www.king5.com/localnews/stories/NW_091108WAB_yates_execution_stayed_TP.68d9d3a3.html?npc | title=Court stays execution for serial killer Yates | publisher=[[KING-TV]] | date=September 11, 2008 | accessdate=September 18, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In 2013 Yates's attorneys filed a ''[[habeas corpus]]'' petition in federal district court, stating that Yates is mentally ill and, "through no fault of his own ... suffers from a severe [[paraphilic]] disorder" that predisposed him to commit murder. The still-pending motion is regarded as a "long shot" by most observers. "I don't think Mr. Yates helps his cause by relying on the fact that he's a [[necrophiliac]]," said Pierce County Prosecutor Mark Lindquist.Serial killer Robert Yates Jr. seeks federal appeal of death sentence (May 16, 2013). [http://blogs.seattletimes.com/today/2013/05/serial-killer-robert-yates-jr-seeks-federal-appeal-of-death-sentence/ Seattle ''Times'' archive]. Retrieved September 17, 2014. Yates remains incarcerated at the [[Washington State Penitentiary]]. His case has been further complicated by Washington Governor [[Jay Inslee]]'s 2013 declaration that he would not sign death warrants for anyone on death row while he is in office. Inslee cited the high cost of the appeals process, the randomness with which death sentences are sought, and a lack of evidence that the penalty serves as a deterrent to other criminals.{{cite news|title=Inslee halts executions in state while he is governor|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2022883256_deathpenaltyinsleexml.html|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=February 11, 2014|accessdate=2014-02-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140212015914/http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2022883256_deathpenaltyinsleexml.html|archivedate=February 12, 2014|df=}}{{cite news|title=Washington state to suspend death penalty by governor's moratorium|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/11/washington-state-death-penalty-governor-inslee-suspends|newspaper=The Guardian|date=February 11, 2014|accessdate=2014-02-12}} In July 2015, the Washington Supreme Court once again rejected an effort by Yates to overturn his conviction and death sentence.{{cite news|title=Supreme Court rejects serial killer Yates' petition to overturn death sentence|url=http://q13fox.com/2015/07/09/supreme-court-rejects-serial-killer-yates-petition-to-overturn-death-sentence/ | publisher=Q13FOX | date=July 9, 2015 | accessdate=December 10, 2015}} After the Washington State Supreme Court ruled in 2018 that the death penalty violated the state constitution, Yates's death sentence, as well as that of Washington's other death row inmates, was commuted to life in prison without the possibility of parole.{{cite web|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/list-of-inmates-whose-sentences-are-changed-from-death-row-to-life-in-prison/|title=List of inmates whose sentences are changed from death row to life in prison |publisher=The Seattle Times|date=October 11, 2018|accessdate=October 12, 2018}} ==Victims== {| class="wikitable" style="vertical-align:top;" colspan=15 style="background:#efefef;" |- !Name!!Date of discovery |- |Patrick Oliver||July 13, 1975 |- |Susan Savage||July 13, 1975 |- |Stacy E. Hawn||December 28, 1988 |- |Shannon Zielinski||June 14, 1996 |- |Patricia Barnes||August 25, 1996 |- |Heather Hernandez||August 26, 1997 |- |Jennifer Joseph||August 26, 1997 |- |Darla Scott||November 5, 1997 |- |Melinda Mercer||December 7, 1997 |- |Shawn Johnson||December 18, 1997 |- |Shawn A. McClenahan||December 26, 1997 |- |Laurie Wason||December 26, 1997 |- |Sunny Oster||February 8, 1998 |- |Linda Daveys||April 1, 1998 |- |Linda M. Maybin||April 1, 1998{{Cite web|url=http://murderpedia.org/male.Y/y/yates-robert-lee-victims.htm|title=Robert Lee Yates {{!}} Victims {{!}} Murderpedia, the encyclopedia of murderers|last=Blanco|first=Juan Ignacio|website=murderpedia.org|access-date=2018-11-11}} |- |Melody Murfin||May 12, 1998 |- |Michelyn Derning||July 7, 1998 |- |Connie LaFontaine Ellis||October 13, 1998 |} ==See also== *[[List of death row inmates in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/yates/bodies_1.html Robert Lee Yates, Jr.] at [[Crime Library]] *[http://www.karisable.com/skazyates.htm Kari & Associates – Robert Lee Yates, Jr.] {{DEFAULTSORT:Yates, Robert Lee}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American aviators]] [[Category:American army personnel of the Gulf War]] [[Category:American murderers of children]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:American prisoners sentenced to death]] [[Category:American serial killers]] [[Category:Crimes against sex workers]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Washington (state)]] [[Category:People from Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:People from Walla Walla, Washington]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to death by Washington (state)]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:American male criminals]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]]

'''Ron Scot Fry''' is the former entertainment and [[artistic director]] of the [[Bristol Renaissance Faire]]. He is also a college professor, a writer, director, artist and performer. He has two children.
==Work history== Fry was the entertainment director of the [[Bristol Renaissance Faire]] from 1989 until 2008.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NS&p_theme=ns&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB1F342945CA6AA&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=Newsbank}}</ref> He also filled several other roles such as teacher, designer, technician, Fight Cast director and performer.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2308150/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ronscotfry.com/RSF_Site/Home.html |title=Home |publisher=Ronscotfry.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=resources&id=6243789|title=21st annual Bristol Renaissance Faire|date=July 7, 2008|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]|accessdate=2009-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ronscotfry.com/RSF_Site/Curriculum_Vitae.html |title=Ron Scot Fry |publisher=Ron Scot Fry |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://onmilwaukee.com/myOMC/blog/show/2955 |title=Reader Blogs |publisher=OnMilwaukee.com |date=2009-07-08 |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref>
As entertainment director, Fry was a key player in the success of the [[Bristol Renaissance Faire]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MWSB&p_theme=mwsb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F57FECF790E5307&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=Newsbank}}</ref> His approach to [[street theatre]] helped to make the Bristol Faire an interactive [[Renaissance Faire]].<ref>http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-100432771.html</ref> In 1989, Fry started BAPA, the Bristol Academy for the Performing Arts, where young performers learned how to speak [[Early Modern English|Olde English]], fight with swords, interact with guests and develop [[improvisation]]al skills. Fry brought in teachers from Chicago's [[The Second City|Second City]] and [[The Players Workshop]]. He oversaw most of the acts at the Bristol Faire and directed all of the faire's [[scenario]] shows, much of the [[street theatre]], and all new performers coming into BAPA.
Fry founded the Bristol Academy for the Performing Arts (BAPA),<ref>{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/31843358.html?dids=31843358:31843358&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jul+12%2C+1998&author=Meg+Murphy.+Special+to+the+Tribune.&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=It+may+require+just+a+jaunt+across+the+Illinois-Wisconsin+border&pqatl=google | work=Chicago Tribune | title=It may require just a jaunt across the Illinois-Wisconsin border | first=Meg | last=Murphy | date=July 12, 1998}}</ref> which held classes in movement, character development, street, commedia dell'arte, and [[improvisation]].<ref>[http://www.bristolrenaissancefaire.com/bristol/participant/involved.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040213103041/http://www.bristolrenaissancefaire.com/bristol/participant/involved.php |date=February 13, 2004 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.renfair.com/bristol/index.php Bristol Faire website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fry, Ron Scot}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American theatre directors]] [[Category:Renaissance fair]]

{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{Israel-Palestinian peace process}} The '''Sharm El Sheikh Memorandum''', full name: '''The Sharm El Sheikh Memorandum on Implementation Timeline of Outstanding Commitments of Agreements Signed and the Resumption of Permanent Status Negotiations''' was a [[memorandum]] signed on September 4, 1999 by [[Prime Minister of Israel]] [[Ehud Barak]] and [[PLO]] Chairman [[Yasser Arafat]] at [[Sharm el Sheikh]] in [[Egypt]], overseen by the [[United States]] represented by [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Madeleine Albright]]. The memorandum was witnessed and co-signed by President [[Hosni Mubarak]] of Egypt and King [[Abdullah II of Jordan|Abdullah]] of [[Jordan]].
== Purposes ==
The memorandum's purpose was to implement the [[Interim Agreement on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip]] (Oslo II) of September 1995 and to implement all other agreements between the PLO and Israel since September 1993: [[Protocol on Economic Relations]] (1994); [[Gaza–Jericho Agreement|Agreement on the Gaza Strip and the Jericho Area]] (1994); [[Israel–Jordan peace treaty|Washington Declaration]] (1994); [[Agreement on Preparatory Transfer of Powers and Responsibilities Between Israel and the PLO]] (1994); [[Protocol on Further Transfer of Powers and Responsibilities]] (1995); [[Wye River Memorandum]] (1998).
To sum up the memorandum: :''In an effort to break the deadlocked Israel-PA negotiations, the parties met in Sharm El Sheikh in the presence of Secretary Albright, President Mubarak and King Abdullah, and signed an agreement which called for the Israeli withdrawal from a further 11% of the West Bank; the release of 350 Palestinian prisoners; the opening of safe passages between the West Bank and Gaza; and a seaport to be built in Gaza. There was also a timetable for final status talks to deal with Jerusalem, borders, refugees and settlements. A framework agreement on permanent status (FAPS) was to be achieved by February 2000 and permanent agreement by September 2000.'' [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Peace/ses_speeches.html]
== Redeployments ==
The two sides agreed to resume Permanent Status negotiations to reach a Permanent Status Agreement. They reaffirmed that negotiations on the Permanent Status would lead to the implementation of Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. Both sides agreed to make a determined effort to conclude a framework agreement and established a timetable to achieve this goal.
Israel and Palestine agreed on a number of Israeli redeployments.
(Note: Area A - Full control of the [[Palestinian Authority]].
Area B - Palestinian civil control, [[Israel Defense Forces|Israeli military]] control.
Area C - Full Israeli control.)
# On September 5, 1999, to transfer 7% from Area C to Area B.
# On November 15, 1999, to transfer 2% from Area B to Area A and 3% from Area C to Area B.
# On January 20, 2000, to transfer 1% from Area C to Area A, and 5.1% from Area B to Area A.
== Other stipulations ==
* Various committees to monitor redeployments and the return to civilian life. * Safe passage routes and crossing points. * A high level Joint Liaison Committee, which would convene no later than September 13, 1999 to review the situation in the [[Tomb of the Patriarchs]] / ''Al Haram Al Ibrahimi''
The memorandum states that neither side would initiate or take any step that would change the status of the [[West Bank]] and the [[Gaza Strip]] in accordance with the Interim Agreement. This clause recognized the necessity to create an appropriate environment for negotiations,
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators also discussed various issues:
* Needs for the peaceful and normal functioning of the [[Gaza City|Gaza]] sea port and airport. * The release of [[Palestinian prisoners]] from Israeli military jails. * Anti-terrorism security. Both sides affirmed they would act swiftly against any threat or act of [[terrorism]], violence or incitement, whether committed by Palestinians or Israelis.
Palestine and Israel also called upon the international donor community to enhance its financial support for the Palestinian economic development and the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Peace/sharm0999.html Full text of the Memorandum] **[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Peace/ses_speeches.html Speeches at the Signing of the Sharm el-Sheikh Memorandum] **[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/sharmmap.html Map for the first Israeli redeployment after the Sharm al-Sheikh Agreement] **[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/sharmmap2.html Map for the second Israeli redeployment after the Sharm al-Sheikh Agreement]

{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Isaac Tutumlu]] | champion team = | manufacturer = | current_season = | website = }} The '''Spanish GT Championship / Iber GT''' (''Campeonato de España de GT / Iber GT'') was a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[auto racing]] series founded in 1999 and organised by the GT Sport Organización. The series runs multiple classes of [[grand tourer]] cars in events around Spain and [[Portugal]]. The series later formed the basis for the [[International GT Open]], a European-wide series which follows a similar structure. ==Format== For racing events, Spanish GT has changed very little since its inception. Each even consists of two races of equal distance, one run on Saturday and the other on Sunday. Each race has its own qualifying session to determine the grid. The races both count towards the points championship, effectively doubling the series schedule. Initially, three classes of cars were used for the series, termed GT2, GT3, and GT4. This was soon replaced by the GTA, GTB, and GTC classes. These cars ranged from the [[FIA]]'s GT2 class equivalent down to cars from [[One-Design|one make]] series. The slowest class, GTC, was eliminated in 2001, only to return in 2004. A new GTS class was introduced in 2005, initially for the custom-built [[SEAT Toledo]] GT, but was adapted in 2006 to use cars from the [[FIA GT3 European Championship]], originally without scoring points in the first year. In the current format, the GTA class is dominated by the [[Ferrari F430]] GT2, [[Porsche 911 GT3]]-RSR, [[Mosler MT900]]R, and the custom-built Sun Red SR21. GTS uses GT3 versions of the Ferrari F430, Porsche 911, [[Lamborghini Gallardo]] and [[Dodge Viper]] Competition Coupe. GTB is retained for one-make cup regulation versions of the F430 and 911, as well as the [[Marcos (automobile)|Marcos Mantis]]. The Spanish GT Championship shares several race weekends with the [[European F3 Open Championship]], also run by the GT Sport Organización. ==Champions== An overall combined drivers championship is awarded each season, adding overall points to class points, which can mean a driver from a lower class of car can be crowned the series champion.
